Chapter 5.1
R-3 MULTIPLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL
11-5.1-1: REGULATIONS APPLICABLE:
The following regulations set forth in this Chapter shall apply in the R-3 Multiple-Family Zone unless otherwise provided in this Title. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-
92)
11-5.1-2: PERMITTED USES:
(A) Any uses permitted in the R-2 Zone without first securing a conditional use permit.
(B) Multiple dwellings subject to the provisions of Chapter 20.1, Site Plan Review.
(C) Accessory buildings and structures. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-92)
(D) (Rep. by Ord. 95-9, 8-7-95)
(E) For general provisions and exceptions see Chapter 20 of this Title. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-92)
11-5.1-3: USES PERMITTED SUBJECT TO FIRST SECURING A CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT:
(A) Dwelling groups consisting of two (2) or more separate one-family dwelling units on a single site, subject to the provisions of Chapter 20.1, Site
Plan Review.
(B) Offices and clinics for the practice of medicine, dentistry and other healing arts, medical and dental laboratories; but excluding veterinarians,
subject to the provisions of Chapter 20.1, Site Plan Review. Pharmacies are permitted, related to and in conjunction with said offices, subject to
sign requirements under the R-3 Zone classification. The site plan submitted for pharmacies must show the relationship of any pharmacy to
surrounding residential uses, if any, and the appearance of commercial development shall be avoided.
(C) Boarding houses, lodging houses, fraternity and sorority houses, subject to the provisions of Chapter 20.1, Site Plan Review.
(D) For general provisions and exceptions see Chapter 20 of this Title. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-92)
11-5.1-4: HEIGHT:
(A) No main building or structure shall have a height greater than two (2) stories not to exceed thirty five feet (35').
(B) No accessory building shall have a height greater than one story not to exceed twelve feet (12') to plate height.
(C) For general provisions and exceptions see Chapter 20 of this Title. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-92)
11-5.1-5: LOT WIDTH:
(A) All lots created after July 5, 1977, shall comply with the following lot width standards and lots existing as of July 5, 1977, may not be reduced below
these standards.
(B) Every lot shall have a minimum lot width of sixty feet (60') excepting that a corner lot shall have a minimum lot width of seventy feet (70').
(C) Reversed corner lots shall have a minimum lot width of seventy five feet (75').
(D) Cul-de-sac or loop out lots shall have a minimum width of forty feet (40') with a minimum lot width at building setback line of sixty feet (60').
(E) Lots siding on freeways and railroads shall have a minimum width of eighty feet (80'). (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-1992)
11-5.1-6: LOT DEPTH:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 303/436
(A) All lots created after July 5, 1977, shall comply with the following lot depth standards and lots existing as of July 5, 1977, may not be reduced
below these standards.
(B) Every lot shall have a minimum lot depth of one hundred feet (100').
(C) Lots backing on freeways and railroads shall have a minimum depth of one hundred thirty feet (130'). (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-1992)
11-5.1-7: FRONT YARD:
(A) Every lot shall have a front yard with a minimum depth of fifteen feet (15'), extending across the full width of the lot, or twenty five percent (25%) of
the depth of the lot, whichever is less, except that when a lot is adjacent to or abuts a lot fronting on the same street zoned R-A, R-1, R-1-9, or R-1-
12, the required front yard setback of the adjacent or abutting lot shall apply for a minimum distance of the first fifty feet (50') extending across the
front of the lot.
(B) For general provisions and exceptions see chapter 20 of this title. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-1992)
11-5.1-8: SIDE YARD:
(A) Every interior lot shall have side yards with a minimum of five feet (5') on each side of the main building, except if an existing lot is less than fifty
feet (50') in width, each side yard shall be a minimum of ten percent (10%) of the width of the lot, or three feet (3'), whichever is more.
(B) For two (2) story multiple-family buildings, a minimum setback of ten feet (10') shall be provided, except when adjoining adjacent properties zoned
for single-family, the second story portion of any building shall have a minimum setback of twenty feet (20').
(C) Corner lots, unless otherwise specified in this code, shall have side yards abutting the street not less than fifteen feet (15') in width, excepting
garages and carports fronting on a street side yard shall be a minimum of twenty feet (20'). For reverse corner lots, the street side yard setback
shall be the same as the minimum front yard setback of the adjacent or abutting lot and shall apply for a minimum distance of the first fifty feet (50')
extending across the street side yard of the lot.
(D) For lots siding on freeways and railroads, the side yard setback adjacent to the freeway for residential structures shall be a minimum of twenty five
feet (25').
(E) For dwelling units oriented to side yards, the minimum requirements of the R-2 zone (subsection 11-4.1-8(E) of this title) shall apply.
(F) For general provisions and exceptions see chapter 20 of this title. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-1992)
11-5.1-9: REAR YARD:
(A) The minimum requirements of the R-2 zone (section 11-4.1-9 of this title) shall apply.
(B) For general provisions and exceptions see chapter 20 of this title. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-1992)
11-5.1-10: BUILDABLE AREA:
The buildable area, or percentage of a lot, which may be occupied by any and all buildings, shall not exceed fifty five percent (55%) except a minor
variance of five percent (5%) of the buildable area or percentage of a lot, which may be occupied by any buildings, may be approved at the discretion
of the community development director where such additional lot coverage will not, in the opinion of the community development director, adversely
affect the aesthetics of the local area. Such variances may be applied only to structures already possessing a certificate of occupancy that are
increasing their existing lot coverage. Lots exceeding the minimum required area as stated in section 11-5.1-12 of this chapter may be allowed to use
seventy percent (70%) of the excess lot for buildable area, provided that the total lot coverage does not exceed fifty five percent (55%) where such
additional lot coverage will not, in the opinion of the community development director, adversely affect the aesthetics of the local area. (Ord. 2002-2, 3-
4-2002)
11-5.1-11: SPACE BETWEEN BUILDINGS:
(A) The minimum requirements of the R-2 zone (section 11-4.1-11 of this title) shall apply.
(B) See section 11-20-8 of this title, accessory buildings. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-1992)
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 304/436
11-1.5-12: LOT AREA:
The minimum lot area requirements of the R-2 zone (section 11-4.1-12 of this title) shall apply. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-1992)
11-5.1-13: POPULATION DENSITY:
Four thousand (4,000) square feet of lot area shall be required for each dwelling unit when two (2) units are located on a single lot. The density shall
not exceed one dwelling unit for each additional three thousand five hundred fifty (3,550) square feet of lot area, plus one dwelling unit for any
remaining area of less than three thousand five hundred fifty (3,550) square feet and more than one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet. (Ord.
92-2, 3-16-1992)
11-5.1-14: OFF STREET PARKING:
(A) For residential uses, the provisions of the R-2 zone (section 11-4.1-14 of this title) shall apply.
(B) For nonresidential uses, the off street parking provisions set forth in chapter 17 of this title shall apply. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-1992)
11-5.1-15: RECREATION AND LEISURE AREAS _ PRIVATE OPEN SPACE:
(A) Usable private open space provided for individual dwelling units shall be a minimum of one hundred fifty (150) square feet for first floor units as
ground floor private open space or sixty (60) square feet minimum for second floor units as balconies.
(B) The minimum requirements of the R-2 zone (subsection 11-4.1-15(B) of this title) shall apply. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-1992)
11-5.1-16: RECREATION AND LEISURE AREAS _ COMMON OPEN SPACE:
The minimum requirements of the R-2 zone (section 11-4.1-16 of this title) shall apply. (Ord. 92-2, 3-16-1992)
Chapter 5.2
R-2-M MULTIPLE-FAMILY MOBILE HOME PARK ZONE
11-5.2-1: REGULATIONS APPLICABLE:
The R-2-M multiple-family mobile home park zone, is intended to provide for accommodation of residential mobile homes in unified parks of not less
than twenty four thousand (24,000) square feet in area and in locations considered appropriate for multiple-family residential land use. (Ord. 693, 7-3-
1972; amd. Ord. 2003-2, 2-18-2003)
11-5.2-2: USES:
In the R-2-M zone, the following uses are permitted, subject to conditional use permit: (Ord. 693, 7-3-1972; amd. Ord. 2003-2, 2-18-2003)
(A) Mobile home parks provided that every such park shall be developed in accordance with the property development standards hereinafter
prescribed.
(B) Accessory uses and buildings incidental to the operation of an approved mobile home park including parking, recreation or utility facilities,
management offices, and signs. (Ord. 693, 7-3-1972)
(C) Sale or resale of fully installed mobile homes, excluding retail commercial sales for off site use.
(D) Display of fully installed model mobile homes for promotion of on site sales and use.
(E) Display of uninstalled model mobile homes for off site sales and for on site sales and use may be permitted by conditional use permit; said permit
shall be terminated after one year unless granted an annual extension by the planning commission. (Ord. 711, 12-3-1973)
(F) Rental of spaces for short term use by travel trailers or recreational vehicles may be permitted in a separate, designated section of a mobile home
park when specifically authorized by a condition of approval of a conditional use permit for a mobile home park. Short term use shall mean an
individual or cumulative period of occupancy within the mobile home park of not more than thirty (30) days during any twelve (12) month period.
(Ord. 751, 8-16-1976)
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 305/436
11-5.2-3: HEIGHT:
Building height shall not exceed thirty five feet (35'). (Ord. 693, 7-3-1972)
11-5.2-4: MOBILE HOME PARK FRONT YARD:
Every mobile home park shall have a front yard with a minimum depth of fifteen feet (15'). (Ord. 751, 8-16-1976)
11-5.2-5: MOBILE HOME PARK SIDE YARD:
Same requirements as R-1 zone (see section 11-3-5 of this title), provided that for structures in excess of one story in height (or 15 feet) the side yards
shall be increased by five feet (5') for each additional story (or for each 10 feet over 15 foot height). (Ord. 751, 8-16-1976)
11-5.2-6: MOBILE HOME PARK REAR YARD:
Same requirements as R-1 zone (see section 11-3-6 of this title), provided that for structures in excess of one story in height (or 15 feet) the rear yard
shall be increased by five feet (5') for each additional story (or for each 10 feet over 15 foot height). (Ord. 751, 8-16-1976)
11-5.2-7: BUILDABLE AREA:
The occupied area of a mobile home lot shall not exceed seventy five percent (75%) of the lot area. (Ord. 756, 9-20-76)
11-5.2-8: DISTANCE BETWEEN MOBILE HOME UNITS OR OTHER PERMITTED BUILDINGS OR STRUCTURES:
(A) The minimum distance between separate buildings shall be ten feet (10'). For accessory buildings, see Section 11-20-8; Section 11-20-8 shall not
be considered applicable to mobile home accessory buildings or structures.
(B) The minimum distance between a mobile home and a building shall be ten feet (10').
(C) The minimum distance required for the separation of a mobile home from any other mobile home shall be: ten feet (10') from side to side, eight feet
(8') from side to rear, and six feet (6') from rear to rear. (Ord. 756, 9-20-76)
11-5.2-9: MOBILE HOME PARK AREA AND DIMENSIONS:
(A) The minimum mobile home park area per mobile home shall be three thousand (3,000) square feet. The minimum area per travel trailer or
recreational vehicle shall be one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet. (Ord. 751, 8-16-76)
(B) The minimum mobile home park area shall be twenty four thousand (24,000) square feet.
(C) Every mobile home park shall have a minimum frontage and width of one hundred twenty feet (120').
(D) Every mobile home park shall have a minimum depth of one hundred twenty feet (120'). (Ord. 693, 7-3-72)
11-5.2-10: OFF-STREET PARKING:
(A) At minimum, one off-street parking space shall be provided for each mobile home lot and travel trailer or recreational vehicle space.
(B) In addition to (A) above, for guest and supplementary resident parking, one space shall be provided for each two (2) mobile home lots and such
additional space shall be developed in accordance with the standards of Chapter 17. This requirement shall not apply to travel trailers or
recreational vehicles. (Ord. 751, 8-16-76)
11-5.2-11: SIGNS:
(Rep. by Ord. 95-9, 8-7-95)
11-5.2-12: OTHER PROPERTY DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 306/436
Except as otherwise required by law or as approved by conditional use permit, the following property development standards shall regulate the design
and improvement of mobile home parks:
(A) Each mobile home shall be located on a separate lot with a minimum width of thirty feet (30') and a minimum lot area of two thousand (2,000)
square feet.
(B) Each travel trailer or recreational vehicle shall be parked on a separate, designated space with a minimum width of twenty five feet (25') and a
minimum aggregate area of one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet.
(C) An aggregate area of not less than three hundred (300) square feet per mobile home lot shall be improved for recreational use of the occupants of
the park, including usable open space and recreation facilities only. This requirement shall not apply to travel trailers or recreational vehicles.
(D) Each mobile home park shall include facilities or areas for bulk storage, laundry, and similar common purposes, unless provided on every
individual lot.
(E) Each mobile home lot shall be designed to accommodate a specific sized mobile home.
(F) No mobile home shall be located closer than three feet (3') from a side or rear lot line.
(G) No mobile home accessory building or structure shall be located closer than three feet (3') from any lot line which does not border on a driveway,
except as follows:
1. A mobile home lot may accommodate either an awning or a carport on a lot line, provided the awning or carport is constructed of material which
does not support combustion and is not less than three feet (3') from a mobile home, a mobile home accessory building or structure on an
adjacent lot, or any other building or structure. No part of an awning or carport shall project over or beyond a lot line.
2. No mobile home accessory structure shall be installed so as to block emergency exit windows in the bedrooms of mobile homes.
3. A free-standing carport, or a common free-standing carport for the use of the occupants of the adjacent mobile home lots, may be erected on a
mobile home lot line, provided that such a carport is constructed of material which does not support combustion, and provided that there is a
minimum of three feet (3') clearance from a mobile home or any other structure on the adjacent lots. Such free-standing carports may be
connected to a mobile home or other accessory building or structure by an open covered walkway not exceeding six feet (6') un width.
(H) Travel trailer or recreational vehicle spaces shall not exceed ten percent (10%) of the total number of mobile home lots in the mobile home park.
(Ord. 756, 9-20-76)
Chapter 5.3
C-O COMMERCIAL OFFICE ZONE
11-5.3-1: REGULATIONS APPLICABLE:
The following regulations shall apply in the C-O commercial office zone, unless otherwise provided in this title. (Ord. 788, 6-5-1978; amd. Ord. 2003-2,

11-5.3-2: PERMITTED USES:

located on a lot.
(B) Multiple Dwellings: Multiple dwellings, subject to the provisions of chapter 20.1, "Site Plan Review", of this title.
(C) Professional Offices: Administrative, business, general, medical, dental and professional offices other than veterinarian, subject to the provisions of
chapter 20.1, "Site Plan Review", of this title. There shall be no retail sales, storage of stock in trade and storage of equipment not used exclusively
in said offices.
(D) Nurseries: Day nurseries, subject to the provisions of chapter 20.1, "Site Plan Review" of this title.
(E) Accessory: Accessory buildings and structures. (Ord. 788, 6-5-1978)
(F) (Rep. by Ord. 95-9, 8-7-1995)
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 307/436
(G) General Provisions; Exceptions: For general provisions and exceptions, see chapter 20 of this title. (Ord. 788, 6-5-1978)
11-5.3-3: USES PERMITTED SUBJECT TO FIRST SECURING A CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT:
(A) Buildings over one story in height when permitted in subsection 11-5.3-4(A) of this chapter.
(B) Home occupations, subject to conforming with the standards specified in subsection 11-3-2(F) of this title, and provided that the subject lot is
occupied by only one nonconforming dwelling unit. (Ord. 788, 6-5-1978)

(D) Banks and savings and loan associations, subject to the provisions of chapter 20.1, "Site Plan Review", of this title. (Ord. 788, 6-5-1978)
(E) Pharmacies, subject to the provisions of chapter 20.1, "Site Plan Review", of this title. (Ord. 819, 10-6-1980)
11-5.3-4: HEIGHT:
(A) No main building or structure shall have a height greater than one story, not to exceed twenty feet (20'). In the event the building height of an
existing building in an abutting residential or commercial zone exceeds these provisions, this height restriction may be waived subject to first
securing a conditional use permit, such waiver not to exceed the height of the existing abutting building or the maximum building height permitted
in the abutting zone, whichever is lower.
(B) No accessory building shall have a height greater than one story, not to exceed twelve feet (12') to plate height.
(C) For general provisions and exceptions, see Chapter 20. (Ord. 788, 6-5-78)
11-5.3-5: LOT WIDTH:
(A) All lots created after the effective date of this Chapter shall comply with the following lot width standards and lots existing as of said date may not
be reduced below these standards.
(B) Every lot shall have a minimum lot width of sixty feet (60') excepting that a corner lot shall have a minimum lot width of seventy feet (70').
(C) Reversed corner lots shall have a minimum lot width of seventy five feet (75').
(D) Cul-de-sac or loop-out lots shall have a minimum width of forty feet (40'), with a minimum lot width at building setback line of sixty feet (60'). (Ord.
788, 6-5-78)
11-5.3-6: LOT DEPTH:
(A) All lots created after the effective date of this Chapter shall comply with the following lot depth standard and lots existing as of said date may not be
reduced below this standard.
(B) Every lot shall have a minimum lot depth of one hundred feet (100'). (Ord. 788, 6-5-78)
11-5.3-7: FRONT YARD:
(A) Every lot shall have a front yard with a minimum depth of fifteen feet (15'). This yard shall be landscaped and maintained.
(B) For general provisions and exceptions, see Chapter 20. (Ord. 788, 6-5-78)
11-5.3-8: SIDE YARD:
(A) Every interior lot shall have side yards with a minimum of five feet (5') on each side of the main building.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 308/436
(B) Corner lots, unless otherwise specified in this Code, shall have side yards abutting the street not less than fifteen feet (15') in width, excepting
garages and carports fronting on a street side yard shall be set back a minimum of twenty feet (20'). The first fifteen feet (15') of a required side
yard abutting a street shall be landscaped and maintained.
(C) Dwelling units oriented to side yards. In addition to the regulations specified in 11-5.3-8(A) and (B), the following regulations shall apply when
dwelling units face or back upon side yards:
1. When dwelling units back upon a side yard with direct access by door to the dwelling unit, the required side yard shall be ten feet (10'). Porches
and steps mentioned in Section 11-20-11 shall be permitted, provided not less than five feet (5') of the width of the required side yard shall be
completely free of structures. Said side yard shall not be used for parking.
2. When dwelling units face upon a side yard, the required width of the side yard shall not be less than fifteen feet (15'). Porches and steps
mentioned in Section 11-20-11 shall be permitted. Said side yard may not be used for parking.
(D) For general provisions and exceptions, see Chapter 20. (Ord. 788, 6-5-78)
11-5.3-9: REAR YARD:
(A) Every lot shall have a rear yard with a minimum depth of ten feet (10').
(B) For general provisions and exceptions, see Chapter 20. (Ord. 788, 6-5-78)
11-5.3-10: BUILDABLE AREA:
The buildable area, or percentage of a lot which may be occupied by any and all buildings, shall not exceed fifty five percent (55%). (Ord. 788, 6-5-
1978)
11-5.3-11: SPACE BETWEEN BUILDINGS:
(A) No requirements for nonresidential buildings.
(B) The space between separate dwellings in dwelling groups or buildings in groups of multiple-family buildings shall not be less than ten feet (10'),
except when said dwellings shall be situated front to rear, front to front, or rear to rear with entry(ies) or exit(s) into said space, the minimum space
shall be fifteen feet (15').
(C) See section 11-20-8, "Accessory Buildings", of this title. (Ord. 788, 6-5-1978)
11-5.3-12: LOT AREA:
(A) All lots created after the effective date of this chapter shall comply with the following lot area standards and lots existing as of said date may not be
reduced below these standards.
(B) The minimum area of a lot shall be six thousand (6,000) square feet, except that corner lots shall contain seven thousand (7,000) square feet of
area, and reversed corner lots shall contain seven thousand five hundred (7,500) square feet of area. (Ord. 788, 6-5-1978)
11-5.3-13: POPULATION DENSITY:
(A) When two (2) or more dwelling units are located on a single lot, a minimum lot area of four thousand (4,000) square feet shall be required for the
first unit and one thousand (1,000) square feet of lot area shall be required for each additional second through sixth units. Each additional unit over
six (6) shall require one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet of lot area. (Ord. 788, 6-5-1978)
11-5.3-14: FENCES, HEDGES AND WALLS:
(A) Where a C-O lot sides or rears on residential zones, a solid masonry wall not less than five feet (5') nor more than six feet (6') in height shall be
erected along said property line, except as provided in subsection (B) of this section.
(B) No fence, wall or hedge over three feet (3') in height shall be permitted in any required front yard or in the required side yard on the street side of a
corner or a reversed corner lot. (Ord. 788, 6-5-1978; amd. Ord. 2003-2, 2-18-2003)

11-5.4-7: FRONT YARD:

landscaping. (Ord. 902, 7-5-88)
11-5.4-8: SIDE YARD:
(A) Every interior lot shall have side yards with a minimum of five feet (5') on each side of the main building.
(B) Corner lots shall have side yards abutting the street not less than fifteen feet (15').
(C) Dwelling units oriented to side yards:
1. When dwelling units back upon a side yard with direct access by door to the dwelling unit, the required side yard shall be ten feet (10'). Porches
and steps mentioned in Section 11-20-11 shall be permitted, provided not less than five feet (5') of the width of the required side yard shall be
completely free of structures. Said side yard shall not be used for parking.
2. When dwelling units face upon a side yard, the required width of the side yard shall not be less than fifteen feet (15'). Porches and steps,
mentioned in Section 11-20-11, shall be permitted. Said side yard may not be used for parking. (Ord. 902, 7-5-88)
11-5.4-9: REAR YARD:
(A) Every lot shall have a rear yard with a minimum depth of ten feet (10'). A minimum five feet (5') rear yard setback for parking only shall be required.
(Ord. 902, 7-5-88)
11-5.4-10: BUILDABLE AREA:
The buildable area, or percentage of a lot which may be occupied by any and all buildings, shall not exceed fifty five percent (55%). (Ord. 902, 7-5-88)
11-5.4-11: SPACE BETWEEN BUILDINGS:
(A) No requirements for nonresidential buildings.
(B) The space between separate dwellings in dwelling groups or buildings or groups of multiple-family buildings shall not be less than ten feet (10'),
except when said dwellings shall be situated front to rear, front to front, or rear to rear with entry(ies) or exit(s) into said space, the minimum space
shall be fifteen feet (15').

reduced below these standards.
(B) The minimum area of a lot shall be ten thousand (10,000) square feet in area. (Ord. 902, 7-5-88)
11-5.4-13: POPULATION DENSITY:

11-7-4: FRONT YARD:
(A) Where a lot in a C-R zone is located in the same block as, and has a common frontage with, a lot or lots in any residential zone, the minimum front
yard depth of such lot in such portion of the C-R zone shall be a minimum of fifteen feet (15') or ten percent (10%) of the depth of the lot, whichever
is less. Such space may be used for off street parking.
(B) For general provisions and exceptions, see chapter 20 of this title. (Ord. 2003-2, 2-18-2003)
11-7-5: SIDE YARD:
(A) There shall be no side yard requirement except as follows:
1. Where a lot abuts upon the side of a lot in any residential zone, there shall be a side yard of a minimum width of five feet (5').
2. Where the rear of a corner lot abuts upon the rear of a lot in any residential zone, the side yard on the street side shall have a minimum of fifteen
feet (15').
3. Where the rear of a reversed corner lot abuts upon a lot in any residential zone, the side yard on the street side of the reversed corner lot shall
be a minimum of fifteen feet (15'), or the required front yard requirements of the lot in the rear (key lot), whichever is less.
(B) For general provisions and exceptions, see chapter 20 of this title. (Ord. 2003-2, 2-18-2003)
11-7-6: REAR YARD:
(A) Rear yard depth shall be a minimum of ten feet (10'). Where a lot backs upon a dedicated alley, no rear yard shall be required.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 313/436
(B) For general provisions and exceptions, see chapter 20 of this title. (Ord. 2003-2, 2-18-2003)
11-7-7: HEIGHT:
(A) No building shall exceed a height of seventy five feet (75').
(B) For exceptions and general provisions, see section 11-20-4 of this title. (Ord. 2003-2, 2-18-2003)
11-7-8: OTHER LIMITATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS:
(A) Landscape and irrigation plans and required fees for all development plans for review and approval by the community development department
prior to issuance of building permits. Landscape plans shall be prepared by a landscape designer, a licensed landscape architect or other qualified
person. Landscaping and irrigation shall be in accordance with the approval plan. Applications for development plans shall include plans and
written material showing how any applicable site landscaping or planting area requirements are to be met. Irrigation plans shall contain all
construction details for an automatic system, including, but not limited to, the following:
1. Location, type and size of lines;
2. Location, type and gallonage output of heads;
3. Location and sizes of valves;
4. Location and type of controller;
5. Installation details;
6. Location and type of backflow prevention device;
7. Available water pressure and water meter outlet size;
8. Irrigation application schedule and flow rates.
(B) All landscaping and irrigation shall be maintained in accordance with International Society of Arboriculture (ISA) pruning guidelines and/or the
American National Scientific Institute (ANSI, A300) pruning standards. Maintenance shall be permanent, and maintenance providers shall be
certified as to these provisions. As used in this section, "maintenance" includes, but is not limited to, watering, weeding, pruning, insect control, and
replacement of plant materials and irrigation equipment as needed to preserve the health and appearance of plant materials. Failure to properly
maintain plant materials to generally accepted standards shall obligate the property owner to replacement of the damaged plant materials.
(C) A minimum of one tree for every six (6) parking spaces shall be distributed throughout the parking lot. Plant materials shall be sized and spaced to
achieve minimum fifty percent (50%) surface area shading in a period not to exceed five (5) years and shall not be less than a fifteen (15) gallon
container for trees, five (5) gallon container for specimen shrubs, and a one gallon container for mass planting. Where shrubs or low level
vegetation are used, vegetative matter at maturity shall cover at least seventy five percent (75%) of actual planted area.
(D) Evidence of completion of required landscaping and irrigation improvements shall be reviewed and approved by the community development
department and the engineering division prior to issuance of an occupancy permit for new construction. (Ord. 2003-2, 2-18-2003)

11-8-10: PACKAGED ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE SALES:
(A) Applicability: This Section shall apply to all retail facilities that sell packaged alcoholic beverages, except for retail facilities which are equal to or
greater than fifteen thousand (15,000) square feet in area and where the display and storage areas for alcoholic beverages constitute less than ten
percent (10%) of the floor area of the establishment.
(B) Conditional Use Permit Required: All facilities as specified in Section 11-8-10(A), shall require a conditional use permit.
(C) Development Standards: The following development standards shall apply to all applicable uses as specified in Section 11-8-10(A):
1. Store Security: The following measures shall be incorporated into all new facilities:
(a) Operational Security: A minimum of one of the following operational security measures shall be used:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 316/436
(1) Timed access safe.
(2) Silent alarm.
(3) Video cameras.
(4) California POST certified security guards.
(b) Store Interior Visibility:
(1) The cashier area shall be easily observable from the street and parking areas.
(2) All parking areas shall be visible from inside the store.
(3) A maximum of thirty percent (30%) visual obstruction of all window areas will be permitted, including but not limited to signs, shelves,
freezers and similar visual obstructions.
(c) Parking Lot Lighting: A minimum of one foot-candle maintained shall be provided in all parking areas and areas of pedestrian travel,
including, but not limited to: parking lots, sidewalks, entrances, service entrances, trash enclosure areas and similar areas where pedestrians
commonly travel.
2. Consumption and Loitering on Premises: No consumption of alcohol or loitering on premises shall be permitted at any time.
(a) Property Posting: The property shall be clearly posted in English and Spanish:
No Loitering. Possession of Opened Alcoholic Beverages on these Premises and Adjacent Public Areas is Prohibited pursuant to Selma
Municipal Code Title 6, Chapter 20.
The owner or his authorized representative shall report all loitering and illegal activities on and adjacent to the subject property to the Police
Department.
(b) Public Phones: No exterior public phones shall be permitted. Interior public phones shall be visible from the cashier area. Only one interior
public phone shall be permitted.
(c) Video Games Prohibited: No video games, pool tables or similar electronic or mechanical devices shall be permitted on the premises.
3. Store Appearance: The property shall be kept free of trash and debris and maintained in good repair at all times.
(a) Trash and Litter Control: A minimum of one trash receptacle shall be provided for every ten (10) required parking spaces or fraction thereof.
The receptacles shall be located where they are easily accessed and do not block pedestrian or vehicular access or create a safety hazard. All
trash receptacles shall be regularly emptied and emptied when they become full.
(b) Temporary Signs: No temporary signage shall be placed on any wall, sign or structure on the property without first obtaining a sign permit.
(D) Density: The following criteria shall be used to determine the density of facilities under this Section in the City:
1. All facilities shall be a minimum of three hundred feet (300') from any public park and any public or private school.
2. All facilities shall be a minimum of five hundred feet (500') from any existing nonexempt facility which conducts retail sales of packaged alcoholic
beverages.
(E) Existing Uses: All existing uses to which these regulations are applicable shall be considered legal nonconforming uses in regards to the
Conditional Use Permit requirement until such time as the use is expanded or modified, or the use is discontinued for a period of three (3) months
or longer, or the use changes in character or mode. All existing uses shall immediately comply with Municipal Code subsections 11-8-10(C)1(b),
(C)2(a), and (C)3. All existing uses are encouraged to comply with all provisions of this Municipal Code Section. (Ord. 94-9, 8-1-94)

11-9-3: LIMITATIONS ON USES:
(A) No manufacturing or processing of any article or commodity shall be permitted, except as follows:
1. Only where incidental to a permitted use.
2. Only where sold at retail on the premises.
3. Only where not more than five (5) persons are engaged in such manufacturing or processing.
4. Only where all such manufacturing or processing conducted on the premises is not obnoxious or offensive by reason of noise, odor, refuse, heat,
glare, dust, smoke, vibration or other similar causes.
(B) All uses shall be conducted wholly within a building, enclosed on all sides, excepting:
1. Advertising signboards or structures.
2. Christmas tree sales.
3. Super service stations.
4. Nurseries.
5. Drive-in restaurants.
6. Public and private parking.
7. Other similar uses customarily conducted in the open.
(C) Wholesale sales and services shall not be conducted.
(D) No use shall be permitted in the C-2 Zone which may be obnoxious or offensive by reason of noise, dust, smoke, vibrations, heat, glare or refuse
or other similar causes.
(E) Good standard practices generally observed with respect to the operation of the corresponding permitted use specifically enumerated in Section
11-9-2, shall be referred to as a general standard in the interpretation of this Section. (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
(F) In areas within this Zone which are immediately adjacent to residences located in R Zones, there shall be no loading to or unloading from vehicles
or conveyances between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M., excepting perishable goods and items related thereto in
the sale or processing thereof. (Ord. 662, 6-16-69)
11-9-4: HEIGHT:
(A) No building shall exceed a height of seventy five feet (75').
(B) For exceptions and general provisions, see Section 11-20-4. (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
11-9-5: REAR YARD:
Same requirements as C-1 Zone, Section 11-8-7. (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
11-9-6: LOT AREA:
(A) There shall be no minimum lot area requirement, subject to the following exceptions:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 319/436
1. In the case of buildings hereafter erected or structurally altered for purposes of residence or human habitation (such as hotels and apartment
hotels), there shall be a lot area of not less than six hundred (600) square feet per family; provided, however, that this regulation shall not apply
to hotels or apartment hotels where no cooking is done in any individual room, suite or apartment. (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
2. (Rep. by Ord. 693, 7-3-72)
(B) For other exceptions and general provisions, see Chapter 20 of this Title. (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
11-9-7: OFF-STREET PARKING AND LOADING SPACE REQUIREMENTS:
(A) See Chapter 17, Off-Street Parking Requirements.
(B) See Chapter 18, Required Loading Space. (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
11-9-8: LOUNGES, BARS AND NIGHTCLUBS:
(A) Definitions: The following definitions shall apply for the purposes of this Chapter:
BAR: Any property which has been granted a license by the appropriate State agency which allows the sale thereon of either beer and wine or of
distilled spirits by the glass for consumption on the premises.
LOUNGE: A bar at which live entertainment is provided but at which public dancing by patrons is neither encouraged nor allowed.
NIGHTCLUB: A bar at which dancing by patrons is allowed or encouraged. Such definition shall apply whether or not the patrons are dancing to
live or prerecorded music.
(B) Interpretation Of Conditional Use Permit: If a conditional use permit has been issued for use as either a lounge, bar or nightclub, the following rules
of construction shall be applied in interpreting the scope of activities allowed by the permit:
1. Unless the conditional use permit issued by the city specifically authorizes either live entertainment or public dancing by patrons, it is intended to
be a permit for a bar only.
2. If the conditional use permit issued specifically allows for live entertainment but makes no mention of public dancing, it shall be construed to be a
conditional use permit for a lounge only. A public dance permit which is otherwise required by the provisions of title VI, chapter 10 of this code, in
order to provide live entertainment, shall not be required if the property has been designated as a "lounge" under a conditional use permit issued
in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. However, a public dance permit shall be required to hold a public dance on property which has
in effect a conditional use permit which allows its use as a "lounge" but does not specifically authorize use as a nightclub.
3. If the conditional use permit issued specifically allows for public dancing, whether or not it allows for live entertainment, it shall be presumed to
be a conditional use permit for a nightclub. A public dance permit, which is otherwise required by the provisions of title VI, chapter 10 of this
code, in order to hold a public dance or other live entertainment, shall not be required if the property has been designated as a "nightclub" under
a conditional use permit issued in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
(C) Clarification: The foregoing is a clarification of existing law. In adopting this section the city council declares the foregoing to be an accurate
statement of the city's intent under existing law. The content of this section, therefore, may be relied upon in the interpretation of conditional use
permits issued by the city prior to the date of the ordinance which added this section to this code. (Ord. 93-2, 3-1-1993)
11-9-9: OVERNIGHTER OR TRAVEL TRAILER ACCOMMODATIONS:
(A) Each overnighter or travel trailer accommodation space shall have an aggregate area of not less than one thousand five hundred (1,500) square
feet and shall be not less than twenty five feet (25') in width.
(B) Recreation areas shall not be required for overnighter or travel trailer accommodations. (Ord. 682, 3-15-1971, eff. 4-15-1971)

Good standard practices generally observed with respect to the operation of the corresponding permitted use specifically listed in section 11-12-2
of this chapter, shall be referred to as a general standard in interpretation of this provision.
(B) No uses shall be permitted in an M-1 zone which are listed or described in section 11-14-2, "Uses", or 11-14-3, "Extra Heavy M-2 Uses Requiring
Conditional Use Permit", of this title, except as specifically provided in section 11-12-2 of this chapter.
(C) Retail facilities that sell packaged alcoholic beverages are prohibited in the M-1 zone.
(D) Emergency shelters shall conform to all of the following regulations:
1. The maximum number of beds or persons permitted to be served nightly by the facility shall be forty (40).
2. On and off street parking shall be determined pursuant to a site plan review or other review as dictated by the requirements of the zone in which
the emergency shelter is to be located.
3. Client intake and waiting areas should be located, whenever possible, on the interior of the emergency shelter subject to a site plan review or
other review based on the proposed operational statement of the applicant.
4. All emergency shelters located within any zone of the city shall have on site management twenty four (24) hours a day. The number of on site
managers shall be determined pursuant to a site plan or other review of the project based on the applicant's operational statement.
5. Emergency shelters shall be located at least three hundred feet (300') apart unless a waiver is granted by the community development director
or his or her designee.
6. The length of stay should be limited to the amount of time necessary to transition a client from emergency housing to transitional or supportive
housing, with a goal of less than thirty (30) days per one hundred eighty (180) day period.
7. Lighting and security requirements shall be determined as part of a site plan or other review using the applicable development standards in the
zone where the emergency shelter is to be located. (Ord. 2015-10, 12-7-2015)

Chapter 15
PRECISE PLANNED ZONE
11-15-1: PRECISE PLANNED ZONE; REGULATIONS:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 328/436
The following regulations shall apply in a precise planned zone. (Ord. 533, 6-5-1961)
11-15-2: FINDINGS NECESSARY FOR ESTABLISHMENT:
A precise planned zone may be established after the commission and the council, respectively, have by resolution found as follows:
(A) That the area proposed to be so zoned is generally suitable for the uses permitted in the particular zone classification proposed to be applied to
the area, being one of the zone classifications elsewhere established in this title; but for reasons affecting the public health, safety, comfort and
general welfare, orderly physical growth and development of the city, or any of such reasons, it would not otherwise be appropriate to so zone or
classify said area, unless the land uses permitted in the said area are subject to a precise plan as herein mentioned, or that the proposed precise
plan is particularly suitable to the orderly physical growth and development of a particular area of the city, subject to the general zone classification
presently in effect in such area.
(B) That the proposed precise plan will provide benefits and safeguards equal to or greater than those that would be provided by the regulations
applicable to the proposed or existing zone classification, as the case may be, with respect to the public health, safety, comfort and general
welfare, orderly physical growth and development of the city.
(C) That all of the owners of the property within the proposed Precise Planned Zone have consented to adoption of the precise plan, in writing, on file
with the Planning Commission.
11-15-3: CONTENT AND SCOPE OF PRECISE PLAN:
(A) A precise plan for a particular Precise Planned Zone may contain regulations and plans relating to the location, height and bulk of buildings and
other improvements; buildable area and open spaces about buildings; traffic control within the Zone; arrangement, design and dimensions of
streets, alleys, pedestrian ways and parking and loading areas; screening of uses from visibility from adjacent areas or public ways, either within or
without the Zone, by fencing or landscaping; and such other matters as in the determination of the Commission and Council may be necessary to
accomplish the purposes of this Chapter.
(B) The precise plan shall be embodied in a map or a written statement, or a combination of same, which shall constitute a part of the Zoning Map of
the City and this Title.
(C) The Zone shall be designated on the Zoning Map by use of the symbol which is otherwise used to designate the general zone classification for
such zone, followed by the letter "P" to indicate that such is a Precise Planned Zone. The precise plan shall be designated by an identifying serial
number, which shall appear on the Zoning Map following the aforementioned symbols designating the zone, and which serial number shall appear
on any map, plan or written statement in which the precise plan is embodied. The provisions of this subsection shall be deemed to be directory
rather than mandatory.
11-15-4: ADOPTION AND AMENDMENT:
(A) The Zone and the approved precise plan therefor and any amendments thereto shall be established by ordinance, upon making the findings
mentioned in Section 11-15-2, and after the same proceedings as in the case of other zones mentioned in this Title.
(B) The Precise Planned Zone may be established at any time, either concurrently with and as a part of the same proceedings for the establishment or
change of a zone classification, or with respect to any established zone.
11-15-5: EFFECT OF PRECISE PLAN:
(A) The use of land and the erection, reconstruction or structural alteration and use of buildings and structures located in a Precise Planned Zone shall
be in conformity with the precise plan, and shall also be in conformity with and subject to all other regulations and provisions which apply, or
thereafter apply, to the general zone classification of the Precise Planned Zone to the extent that they are not contrary to the express provisions or
general intent of the precise plan.
(B) The provisions of a precise plan shall in any case be subject to the provisions of Chapter 19 relating to nonconforming buildings and uses. (Ord.
533, 6-5-61)

shown on a ten foot (10') grid and shall extend ten feet (10') outside of the property lines.

obtained prior to commencement of operation.

pedestrian gate. Employees will not be permitted to park on either Snyder Street or Rose Avenue. All employee parking must be within the
confines of the Auto Mall. No additional traffic will be added to Snyder Street or Rose Avenue.

landscaping. The maintenance shall be ongoing regardless of ownership of the parcel. EXHIBIT A

11-15-20: R-3-P MULTIPLE-FAMILY PRECISE PLAN ZONE:
(A) The property set forth in zone change application number 97-269 shall be zoned R-3-P (multiple-family residential) precise plan district as
designated in said application.
(B) The precise plan requirements for zone change application number 97-269 shall be as follows:
1. The property development standards of the R-3 zone shall govern the development of the subject property except as specified herein.
2. The placement of all buildings, structures, parking areas, drive aisles and recreation facilities shall be in conformance with the plan attached as
exhibit A to this section. All buildings, structures, parking areas and drive aisles shall be maintained as approved by this precise plan. Minor
changes that do not affect the intent and integrity of the precise plan may be made with the approval of the community development director of
the city.
3. A maximum of eighty nine (89) units shall be permitted on the site and shall be limited to sixty four (64) 1-bedroom units and twenty five (25) 2-
bedroom units. One unit shall be reserved for the residential project manager who shall reside on site. The floor plans of the residential units
shall conform with the floor plans attached as exhibit B to this section. The floor plans of the community building shall conform with the floor plan
attached as exhibit C to this section. Minor dimension and facility adjustments may be approved by the building inspector to comply with
handicapped accessibility requirements for the handicapped units.
4. A minimum of ninety (90) on site parking spaces shall be provided for the complex. Covered parking shall be provided for a minimum sixty one
(61) vehicles. Covered parking shall be provided by carports or enclosed garage buildings. The architectural design of covered vehicular parking
shall be of similar architectural materials as incorporated and used in the housing unit construction. Handicapped spaces shall be provided in
accordance with applicable local, state and federal laws.
5. All building elevations shall conform with the elevations attached as exhibits D and D-1 to this section as approved except for fence height
details of the wrought iron fence and except as pertains to the proposed carport. Carports shall be constructed with stucco support columns
matching other buildings in materials and color. Carport roofs shall incorporate mansard construction design with tile, metal clad roofing or other
architectural treatment that match materials and colors of the main building designs of the project. The proposed architectural treatments shall be
approved by the Community Development Director prior to issuance of building permits. Architectural features for all buildings with front or side
orientation to Evergreen Street shall include shutters consistent with treatment on other building elevations.
6. The fences enclosing or screening patio or private open space area shall be constructed of wood frame materials with a stucco finish that
matches the exterior of the building in material and color. Exposed wood fencing shall not be permitted anywhere in the project area except for
the gates of the private patio areas. Any wooden gate provided shall be painted with colors matching the stucco finish or building trim. The
private open space areas shall be a minimum of one hundred fifty (150) square feet of usable area.
7. A seven foot (7') high decorative concrete block wall shall be required along the northerly, westerly and easterly property lines or along
development lines that are common with properties zoned P-M-D (Planned Medical Development) District. Within the front yard area the
masonry wall shall not exceed forty two inches (42"). The masonry block wall shall comply with City standards as to construction. Prior to
construction, plans demonstrating proposed heights, location, and materials shall be submitted to the Community Development Department for
review and approval. Within the area of fifty feet (50') from the front property line, the masonry wall shall incorporate pilasters, at twenty foot (20')
centers, constructed with split faced or other approved decorative concrete block materials and shall be capped appropriately. The colors of the
block fence shall coordinate with building materials.
8. Wrought or ornamental iron fencing and security gates may be provided along the front of the property. Such fencing shall incorporate brick,
decorative masonry block or framed stucco pilasters erected on a maximum of twenty foot (20') centers. Any security gates maintained at the
project entry points shall be designed and equipped in a manner approved by the Selma Police and Fire Chiefs to allow twenty four (24) hour
accessibility for emergency service vehicles.
9. Prior to the issuance of building permits, three (3) copies of a photometric lighting plan shall be submitted and approved by the Community
Development Department. The photometric lighting plan shall be prepared by a licensed electrical engineer. The plan shall meet the following
minimum standards:
(a) No light standards shall exceed a height of twenty feet (20') in the interior of the project and no light standard shall exceed a height of twelve
feet (12') within fifteen feet (15') of any property line. All light standards shall be clearly shown and labeled as to type and height on the lighting
plan.
(b) Lighting under the carport areas shall be shown on the lighting plan.
(c) A minimum of one-half (1/2) foot-candle, maintained, shall be required for all parking areas, sidewalks, and drive aisles within the project area.
A maximum of a ten to one (10:1) lighting ratio shall be permitted. The expected foot-candle ratings shall be shown on a site plan with
readings shown on a ten foot (10') grid and shall extend ten feet (10') outside of the property lines.
(d) All lighting fixtures shall have sharp cut-off features near the property line. Excessive light and glare outside of the project shall not be
permitted.
(e) All lighting shall be maintained so as to meet the minimum standards set forth by this Section.
10. The site shall be developed in accordance with a landscape plan reviewed and approved by the Community Development Department. The
landscape plan shall identify the size, location and the type of plant materials. The landscape plan shall be approved prior to the issuance of
building permits and shall provide for the following:
(a) Twenty five percent (25%) of the trees on the project site shall be a minimum of two inch (2") caliper size when measured four and one-half
feet (41/2') above the ground. The remainder of the trees shall be a minimum of a one inch (1") caliper size when measured four and one-half
feet (41/2') above the ground.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 346/436
(b) Fifty percent (50%) of the shrubs on the project shall be a minimum five (5) gallon size. All other shrubs shall be of a minimum one gallon
size.
(c) All landscaping shall be installed and growing prior to the final inspection of the project site. All landscaping shall be continually maintained in
accordance with the approved plan.
11. Irrigation plans shall be submitted for review and approval by the Community Development Department prior to installation of any irrigation
system. Low flow and drip irrigation systems shall be utilized except in lawn areas. The applicant or successor in interest shall be responsible for
all fees and materials required for that review.
12. Prior to the installation of any sign, a master plan of signage shall be reviewed and approved by the Community Development Department. All

be applied for under a sign permit. No additional project identification signage shall be permitted. Address and building identification signage
shall be provided prior to the final inspection of the buildings. Address and building identification signage shall be submitted to the Community
Development Department for review and approval by the Community Development, Fire and Police Departments prior to installation.
13. A master address plan for the development shall be developed by the Building Official and Selma Fire Chief prior to the issuance of the first
building permit.
14. The following fire protection measures shall be incorporated into the project:
(a) All portions of the main drive aisle not designated for parking on Exhibit A shall be designated as a fire lane. The fire lane shall be painted
and signed as required by applicable local, State and Federal policies and laws prior to occupancy of any building.
(b) Fire hydrants shall be located as directed by the Selma Fire Chief.
15. Evergreen Street shall be offered for dedication and shall be constructed to City standards from the easterly development line of the senior
citizen housing project to the nearest developed portion of Evergreen Street to the west. The minimum standard for improvement shall be two (2)
12-foot wide travel lanes, parking on the development side eight feet (8') in width and a sidewalk/parkway area ten feet (10') wide. Total minimum
street improvement width shall be forty two feet (42'). Construction shall include turnaround for emergency service vehicles approved by the
Selma Fire Chief and City Engineer. The right of way for turnaround shall be offered for dedication for temporary emergency use. The temporary
use dedication shall be relinquished to the property owner upon completion of additional streets providing adequate emergency vehicular
circulation.
16. Improvements to be constructed shall include street section, concrete curb and gutter, storm drainage, sewer, water and public utility facilities.
17. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued to the applicant or successor in interest until the City has accepted submitted plans that illustrate an
appropriate cul-de-sac turnaround at the end of the frontage of the proposed senior housing project.
18. The developer/owner of the senior citizen complex shall enter into a development agreement with the City assuring the development and
maintenance of the residential development for senior citizen housing for a period of fifty five (55) years as proposed in the application for
rezoning. The development agreement shall also provide for developer/property owner to dedicate one hundred four foot (104') dedication along
the Del Rey Alignment prior to the issuance of permits.
19. The applicant or successor in interest shall be responsible for arranging a pre-design with the City Engineer and Selma-Kingsburg-Fowler,
County Sanitation District.
20. Guest parking shall be designated and made part of the final development plan.

Chapter 15.1
PV PIONEER VILLAGE ZONE
11-15.1-1: REGULATIONS APPLICABLE:
The following regulations shall apply in the PV Pioneer Village Zone, unless otherwise provided in this title. (Ord. 771, 6-20-1977)
11-15.1-2: USES PERMITTED SUBJECT TO FIRST SECURING A CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT:
The establishment or operation of any of the following uses in the PV Zone shall not be permitted unless a conditional use permit and a Master Plan
have been approved under the provisions of this section.
(A) All uses permitted in the residential, commercial and industrial zones.
(B) Indoor and outdoor displays of items commonly considered of historic interest. (Ord. 771, 6-20-1977)
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 363/436
11-15.1-3: LIMITATIONS ON USES:
(A) No uses shall be permitted except those uses designed and operated primarily for the purpose of creating or supporting a functioning historic
display.
(B) No use shall be permitted except those which are consistent with the adopted Master Plan. (Ord. 771, 6-20-1977)
11-15.1-4: DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS:
(A) Access shall be designed to insure safe and convenient vehicular and pedestrian movement, to, from and within the development. The
development shall have access to a public street.
(B) Yards shall be adequate in size to provide for planned landscaping to insure adequate spacing for fire protection purposes and to insure safe sight
distance for movement within the development.
(C) Landscaping shall be provided and maintained. Plants and related materials shall be arranged in a manner which is consistent with and
complementary to the building design and materials.
(D) The number of parking spaces required shall be established by the Planning Commission at the time the conditional use permit is issued. (Ord.
771, 6-20-1977)
11-15.1-5: MASTER PLAN:
A Master Plan showing the extent and character of the entire proposed development shall be submitted. The Master Plan shall be submitted with the
conditional use permit application. The plan, or accompanying narrative, shall include sufficient information to determine that all requirements of this
section have been met, including but not limited to the following:
(A) Proposed uses;
(B) Development standards showing setbacks, yards and landscaping;
(C) Heights of buildings and structures, if known;
(D) Architectural design or theme;
(E) Development phasing;
(F) Services and facilities supporting proposed uses, including vehicular access and parking. (Ord. 771, 6-20-1977)
11-15.1-6: SITE PLAN REVIEW:
Before any building or structure is erected or parcel created under the provisions of this section, a site plan reflecting all conditions of approval shall
have been submitted to and approved by the City Engineer/Planner. Such site plan shall encompass all that area shown on the approved Master Plan.
(Ord. 771, 6-20-1977)
11-15.1-7: EXEMPTIONS:
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Code, events at Pioneer Village shall not be subject to the requirements of title VI, chapter 17 of this
Code. Instead they shall be subject to duly approved policies of the Pioneer Village Commission. (Ord. 2017-4, 11-6-2017)
Chapter 15.2
S-P SPECIFIC PLAN ZONE
11-15.2-1: REGULATIONS APPLICABLE:
The S-P (specific plan) zoning district is hereby established to provide a distinct zoning classification for areas of the city within the boundaries of a
specific plan area. The applicable specific plan is a regulatory document, and upon its adoption, the specific plan for an area covered by the specific
plan shall govern and control all allowable land uses, densities, lot coverage, minimum areas, building height limits, building separation, open space
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 364/436
requirements, signage, landscaping, street widths, architectural design, walls and fences, street lighting, park locations, and all other development and
design related elements within the applicable specific plan area. All approved specific plans will be on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. 2007-6, 6-
4-2007)
11-15.2-2: DESIGNATED SPECIFIC PLAN AREAS:
The following specific plan area designations are hereby established:
(A) S-PA (Amberwood).
(B) S-PNE (northeast).
(C) S-PSS (south Selma).
(D) S-PR (Rockwell).
(E) S-PNW (northwest). (Ord. 2007-6, 6-4-2007)
11-15.2-3: SPECIFIC PLAN AREA BOUNDARIES AND ZONING MAP:
The specific plan area boundaries may be determined by reference to the applicable specific plan and shall be delineated on the official city of Selma
zoning map as adopted by the city council. (Ord. 2007-6, 6-4-2007)
11-15.2-4: PERMITTED USES:
Permitted uses shall be those uses as depicted on the land use map and zoning map of the applicable specific plan for the area or development, and
as outlined in the specific plan text under permitted uses. (Ord. 2007-6, 6-4-2007)
11-15.2-5: CONDITIONAL USES:
Conditional uses shall be those uses as outlined in the applicable specific plan text as conditional uses. (Ord. 2007-6, 6-4-2007)
11-15.2-6: CONTROLLING REGULATORY DOCUMENT:
The applicable specific plan shall be the controlling land use and zoning regulatory document for all land located within the designated boundaries of
the applicable specific plan area. The specific plan land use and development regulations supersede all inconsistent requirements of the city's zoning
ordinance. (Ord. 2007-6, 6-4-2007)
11-15.2-7: PREZONING FOR ANNEXATION:
All land located within the boundaries of a designated specific plan area shall be prezoned to the applicable specific plan area prior to annexation of
the subject property into the city. (Ord. 2007-6, 6-4-2007)
11-15.2-8: MINOR DEVIATIONS:
Minor deviations of up to but not exceeding ten percent (10%) of the development standards for the applicable specific plan area may be approved by
the community development director ("director") upon application by the property owner which application outlines and demonstrates the justifiable
need and reason for the deviation. No deviation which compromises public health and safety in any manner shall be approved. (Ord. 2007-6, 6-4-
2007)
Chapter 16
CONDITIONAL USES
11-16-1: PURPOSE:
Certain uses in all districts and designated uses in certain districts are permitted subject to the granting of a conditional use permit. Because of their
unusual characteristics, or the special attributes of the area in which they are to be located, conditional uses require special consideration so that they
may be properly located with respect to the objectives of the zoning ordinance and their effect on surrounding properties. The planning commission is
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 365/436
empowered to grant and to deny applications for conditional use permits subject to the requirements of this section and to impose reasonable
conditions upon the granting of conditional use permits. (Ord. 766, 4-4-1977)
11-16-2: APPLICATION FOR CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT:
An application for a conditional use permit shall be filed with the secretary of the planning commission on a form prescribed by the planning
commission, which shall include the following information:
(A) Name and address of the applicant.
(B) Statement that the applicant is the owner of the property or is the authorized agent of the owner.
(C) Address and legal description or the assessor's parcel number of the property.
(D) The application shall include an accurate scale drawing of the site and improvements proposed. The drawing must be adequate to enable the
Planning Commission to determine the compliance of the proposal with the requirements of this Ordinance.
(E) Any other data pertinent to the findings prerequisite to the granting of a conditional use permit that may be required by the City.
11-16-3: PLANNING COMMISSION PUBLIC HEARING:
(A) A public hearing shall be held by the Planning Commission not less than ten (10) nor more than forty (40) days after the filing of a complete
application for a conditional use permit, notice of which shall be given in the manner prescribed in Section 11-21-2(C).
(B) At the public hearing, the Planning Commission shall review the application and the statement and drawing submitted therewith and shall receive
pertinent evidence concerning the proposed use and the proposed conditions under which it would be operated or maintained, particularly with
respect to the findings prescribed in Section 11-16-4.
(C) The public hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the rules and procedures specified in Section 11-21-3.
11-16-4: FINDINGS AND CONDITIONS:
The Planning Commission in granting a conditional use permit shall find as follows:
(A) That the site for the proposed use is adequate in size and shape to accommodate said use and all yards, spaces, walls and fences, parking,
loading, landscaping and other features required by this Section to adjust said use with land and uses in the neighborhood.
(B) That the site for the proposed use relates to streets and highways adequate in width and pavement type to carry the quantity and kind of traffic
generated by the proposed use.
(C) That the proposed use will have no adverse effect on property within a three hundred foot (300') radius of the permitted use thereof. In making this
determination, the Planning Commission shall consider the proposed location of improvements on the site; vehicular ingress, egress and internal
circulation, setbacks, height of buildings, walls and fences, landscaping, outdoor lighting, signs, such other characteristics as will affect surrounding
property.
(D) That the conditions stated in the resolution are deemed necessary to protect the public health, safety and general welfare. Conditions may include
the following:
1. Special yards, spaces and buffers.
2. Fences and walls.
3. Enclosure of storage areas and limitation on out of door display of merchandise.
4. Grading, surfacing, and drainage specifications.
5. Regulation of points of vehicular ingress and egress.
6. Regulation of signs.
7. Requiring landscaping and maintenance thereof.
8. Requiring maintenance of the grounds.
9. Requiring fire prevention equipment and measures.

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 366/436
10. Regulation of noise, vibration, odors, etc.
11. Regulation of time for certain activities.

the proposed curb line.
