and purposes set forth in this Section. (Ord. 766, 4-4-77)
(E) That the proposed use is consistent with the Selma General Plan and applicable land use component plans which may establish criteria for
approval and/or standards for development. (Ord. 935, 8-20-90)
11-16-5: PLANNING COMMISSION DECISION:
(A) The Planning Commission may approve, approve with stated conditions, or disapprove the conditional use permit application by resolution. The
resolution shall describe the basis for the decision and state the specific circumstances requiring the conditions to approval.
(B) The Planning Commission shall have forty (40) days after the conclusion of a public hearing to render its decision on the conditional use permit
application. Failure of the Planning Commission to adopt a resolution within the aforementioned forty (40) day period shall be deemed to constitute
a denial of the application.
(C) The decision of the Planning Commission shall be final unless appealed to the Council in accordance with the procedure specified in Section 11-
16-6.
(D) The Planning Commission shall cause a copy of its resolution to be mailed to the applicant within ten (10) days from the date of adoption thereof.
(E) No building or zoning permit shall be issued where a conditional use permit has been approved or conditionally approved by the Planning
Commission until ten (10) days after such permit has been granted by the Planning Commission and then only in accordance with the terms and
conditions of the conditional use permit granted.
11-16-6: APPEAL TO THE CITY COUNCIL:
(A) In case the applicant is not satisfied with the action of the Planning Commission, the applicant may within ten (10) days after the date of mailing, as
shown by the postmark of the papers mentioned in subsection 11-16-5(D), or within ten (10) days after the expiration of the forty (40) day period
mentioned in subsection 11-16-5(B), file in writing with the City Clerk an appeal to the City Council. Said appeal shall state specifically wherein it is
claimed that there was an error or abuse of discretion by the Planning Commission or whereby its decision is not supported by the evidence in the
record.
(B) In case any party other than the applicant is not satisfied with the action of the Planning Commission, said party may within ten (10) days after the
date of adoption of the resolution of the Planning Commission, or within ten (10) days after the expiration of the forty (40) day period mentioned in
Section 11-16-5(B) file in writing with the City Clerk an appeal to the City Council. Said appeal shall state specifically wherein it is claimed that there
was an error or abuse of discretion by the Planning Commission or whereby its decision is not supported by the evidence in the record.
(C) The City Council shall set a date for a public hearing on the appeal and shall post notices as set forth in Section 11-21-2(C). The date for the public
hearing shall not be less than ten (10) nor more than forty (40) days from the date on which the appeal was filed.
(D) Notice shall also be given to the Planning Commission of such appeal, and the Planning Commission shall submit a report to the City Council
setting forth the reason for its action or shall be represented at the hearing.
(E) The City Council may affirm, reverse, or modify a decision of the Planning Commission, provided, however, that if a decision denying a conditional
use permit is reversed or a decision granting a use permit is modified, the City Council shall, on the basis of the record transmitted and such
additional evidence as may be submitted, make the findings prerequisite to the granting of a conditional use permit as prescribed in Section 11-16-
4.
(F) The City Council shall render its decision by resolution within forty (40) days after the conclusion of the public hearing held on the appeal. Failure of
the City Council to adopt a resolution within the aforementioned forty (40) day period shall be deemed to constitute a denial of the appeal.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 367/436
(G) The City Council shall cause a copy of its resolution to be mailed to the applicant within ten (10) days from the adoption thereof.
(H) The decision of the City Council shall be final and shall have immediate effect.
11-16-7: TIME LIMIT FOR DEVELOPMENT:
A conditional use permit shall lapse and shall become void one year following the date on which the conditional use permit became effective unless,
by conditions of the conditional use permit a lesser or greater time is prescribed or unless, prior to the expiration, a building permit is issued by the
building official and construction is commenced, and being diligently pursued in accordance with the conditional use permit. A conditional use permit
may be renewed for an additional period of one year or for a lesser or greater period as may be specified, provided that an application for renewal is
filed with the planning commission prior to the expiration of the time period granted. The commission may grant or deny an application for renewal.
(Ord. 766, 4-4-1977)
11-16-8: USE PERMIT TO RUN WITH THE LAND:
A conditional use permit granted pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall run with the land and shall continue to be valid upon a change of
ownership of the site or structure which was the subject of the use permit application unless a specific time period in which the use permit will be valid
and the use may be operated has been set in accordance with subsection 11-16-4(D)13 of this chapter. (Ord. 766, 4-4-1977)
11-16-9: NEW APPLICATION:
Following the denial of a conditional use permit application or the revocation of a conditional use permit, no application for a conditional use permit for
the same or substantially the same conditional use on the same or substantially the same site shall be filed within one year from the date of denial or
revocation of the conditional use permit. (Ord. 766, 4-4-1977)
11-16-10: REVOCATION OR MODIFICATION OF CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT:
A conditional use permit may be revoked or modified in the manner and under the conditions set forth in chapter 24 of this title. (Ord. 766, 4-4-1977)
11-16-11: UNCLASSIFIED CONDITIONAL USES:
Any use listed below may be permitted in any zone in the city specified in the permit unless otherwise provided in this chapter after the same has been
reviewed and a conditional use permit therefor has been issued in the manner provided hereinabove; and any use listed in this chapter shall not be
permitted in any zone in the city without such review and such permit except in a zone where such use is specifically permitted by this title:
(A) Airports.
(B) Cemeteries.
(C) Churches subject to the provisions of subsection 11-16-12(B) of this chapter.
(D) Columbariums, crematories, and mausoleums, provided that none of the foregoing shall be permitted in any R zone, unless within a cemetery.
(E) Fire and police station.
(F) Golf course or driving range.
(G) Public utility facilities, including water wells, substations, communication equipment buildings, and excluding pole lines and distribution mains.
(H) Radio or television transmitters and wireless and nonwireless telecommunications facilities. Wireless and nonwireless telecommunications facilities
are hereby required to comply with the provisions of subsection 11-16-12(C) of this chapter.
(I) Refuse dumps and disposal.
(J) Mental hospital; provided, such use shall not be permitted in any R zone.
(K) Railroads.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 368/436
(L) Amusement parks, circuses, carnivals or fairgrounds, open air theaters, racetracks and rodeo grounds. (None of the foregoing shall be permitted in
any R zone, except that open air theaters may be allowed in city parks, subject to the provisions of title IX, chapter 8 of this code.)
For purposes of this subsection the following definitions shall apply:
AMUSEMENT PARKS: A commercially operated park with various devices for entertainment and booths for the sale of food and drink.
CARNIVALS OR FAIRGROUNDS: A commercial amusement show having mechanical rides, amusements, games of skill, sideshows and food or
drink for sale. Generally is a traveling show.
CIRCUSES: An exhibition or entertainment at which feats of horsemanship, acrobatics and trained or wild animals are exhibited or displayed, to
which exhibition or entertainment an admission fee is charged.
OPEN AIR THEATERS: An area or place of enactment, natural or manmade, which may have a turf stage, curtains and dressing rooms at which
plays, pageants, concerts, drama activities and meetings are held.
RACETRACKS: A course on which races are run with animals or mechanical devices.
RODEO GROUNDS: A public performance featuring bronco riding, calf roping, steer wrestling and bull riding.
(M) Mortuaries.
(N) Full time elementary, junior high and high schools, public and private, subject to the provisions of subsection 11-16-12(B) of this chapter.
(O) Playgrounds and public parks, exclusive of amusement parks.
(P) Childcare nurseries subject to the provisions of subsection 11-16-12(A) of this chapter.
(Q) Institutional buildings subject to the provisions of subsection 11-16-12(B) of this chapter.
(R) Private clubs and lodges including private recreation clubs.
(S) Rest homes and nursing homes.
(T) Commercial coaches with a commercial seal issued by the state for all uses (office uses) permitted in the commercial and manufacturing zones,
except residential uses, for a period not to exceed one year in length. Mobile homes used as caretaker residences in manufacturing districts are
not considered to be commercial coaches.
(U) Arcades, video or electronic game establishments having six (6) or more amusement machines for use (except within any R zone).
(V) C-3 (commercial service) zoning district hereby establishes the following conditional uses: poolrooms, card rooms, massage establishments, tattoo
parlors, drug paraphernalia shops, or any combination thereof. (Ord. 766, 4-4-1977; amd. Ord. 791, 7-3-1978; Ord. 827, 7-6-1981; Ord. 846, 9-20-
1982; Ord. 96-4, 5-20-1996; Ord. 99-9, 8-16-1999; Ord. 2002-3, 3-4-2002)
11-16-12: SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS ON CERTAIN UNCLASSIFIED CONDITIONAL USES:
(A) Childcare Nurseries; Play Area Requirement:
1. There shall be provided on the lot or on adjacent premises a single play area of not less than seven hundred (700) square feet plus an additional
sixty (60) square feet for each child in excess of ten (10) as shown by the maximum number of children which may be cared for at any time,
pursuant to the license for the nursery.
2. The play area shall not be located in any required front or side yard.
(B) Institutional Buildings; Additional Yard Requirements: Any building erected, altered or used for school or church purposes, or as an institutional
building, shall be located at least fifteen feet (15') from every lot line or any property included in any R zone, notwithstanding any lesser
requirement in the zone where located; provided, such building shall not be required to be located more than five feet (5') from any lot line adjacent
to any alley. With respect to the accessory buildings, the commission shall have authority to waive the foregoing requirements for good cause.
(Ord. 766, 4-4-1977)
(C) Wireless And Nonwireless Telecommunications Facilities:
1. Wireless and nonwireless telecommunications facilities shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the city of Selma wireless and
nonwireless telecommunications facilities standards and design manual, a copy of which is on file with the city clerk and in the community
development department.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 369/436
2. Wireless and nonwireless telecommunications facilities shall not be located inside residential zones, or within three hundred feet (300') of any
residential zone.
3. The requested placement and height of wireless and nonwireless telecommunications facilities shall be proven necessary by sound engineering
practices. Complete engineering reports for location and height requirements must be filed at the time of application for the conditional use
permit (CUP).
4. Wireless and nonwireless telecommunications facilities shall be "Collocated" with existing sites unless sound engineering analysis referenced in
subsection (C)3 of this section show this to create an unreasonable hardship for the applicant. The analysis will reference the location and height
requirements as well as the capacity of existing facilities.
5. The owner of any wireless and/or nonwireless telecommunications facility shall on July 1 of every year provide a statement of the operational
status of any facility they own within the city of Selma to the Selma community development department. Any facility that is not operated for a
continuous period of twelve (12) months or a total of eighteen (18) months in any three (3) year period shall be considered abandoned.
Abandoned wireless and nonwireless telecommunications facilities shall be demolished within ninety (90) days of the owner's receipt of written
notification of the abandonment of the facility. (Ord. 2002-3, 3-4-2002)
(D) Conditional Uses: Conditions applied to unclassified conditional uses pursuant to this section and to subsection 11-16-4(D) of this chapter shall
take precedence over the standards of the zone district in which the use is located. Standards of the zone district in which the use is located shall
apply in all matters not governed by conditions of the use permit. (Ord. 766, 4-4-1977; amd. Ord. 2002-3, 3-4-2002)
11-16-13: EFFECT UPON COUNTY ISSUED CONDITIONAL USE PERMITS WHEN TERRITORY IS ANNEXED TO THE CITY:
County issued conditional use permits shall continue to run with the land when territory is annexed to the city and shall be automatically recognized as
being valid by the city. Following annexation, and upon receipt of conditions of approval from the county, the secretary to the planning commission
shall review the conditions and inform the commission of any violations of the conditions that may be evident after inspection of the property. If all
conditions are being met, the secretary shall so inform the commission. (Ord. 844, 9-7-1982)
11-16-14: SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS ON SECONDARY AUTO REPAIR SERVICES AFTER FUELING SERVICES
DISCONTINUED:
(A) All underground storage facilities for fuel, oil and other petroleum products shall be removed from the site and all contaminants cleaned pursuant to
local, state and/or federal regulations.
1. The permitted secondary auto repair services are limited to the following activities:
(a) Engine tune up and related engine diagnostics.
(b) Battery sales and installation.
(c) Tire sales and repair services with related wheel balancing and alignment.
(d) Oil and lubricant sales with related lube and oil change services.
2. Storage of parts and equipment shall be within enclosed buildings.
3. Used parts and materials shall be stored within enclosed areas. These enclosed areas shall be built to city standards.
4. No overnight storage of inoperative vehicles, or vehicles awaiting, or under repair, except within an enclosed building.
5. Buildings shall be kept in good state of repair and maintained free of substandard conditions.
6. On site signage shall conform to current sign standards and shall be approved as a part of the conditional use permit hearing process.
7. Trash enclosures shall conform to current city standards and shall be maintained.
8. The site shall be landscaped and maintained in accordance with a new landscape plan submitted and approved through the conditional use
permit hearing process.
9. All use areas of the site shall be paved to current city standards. Paved areas shall be striped and marked as required and shall be kept free of
oil and other petroleum contaminants.
10. A "waste and disposal of auto parts and materials plan" shall be submitted for review and approval as part of the conditional use permit hearing
process.
(B) No single retail or service component of the service station business shall be intensified to the point that the business becomes a specialty shop or
multiple specialty shops operated as independent businesses not otherwise permitted in the zoning district. Examples of commercial service
activities that are considered specialty shops are: tire shops, radiator shops, engine repair shops, automotive repair shops, muffler shops or towing
and vehicle storage businesses.
(C) Secondary auto repair services are those services accompanying the primary retail sale of automotive fuel. Code provisions allow the secondary
auto repair services of a permitted service station to continue in the event that the primary retail sale of fuel is discontinued due to the removal of
underground fuel tanks pursuant to state laws.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 370/436
(D) The service station shall have a verifiable history of operation as a bona fide service station with continued service to the present.
(E) This section shall apply to the C-1, C-2, C-H zone districts and any other districts where existing service stations are permitted, but not automotive
garages. It shall also apply to the regulations consistent with the formation of new districts. (Ord. 2000-5, 5-15-2000)
11-16-15: ADMINISTRATIVE CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT:
The community development director, or his or her designee, may issue an administrative conditional use permit for all uses requiring such permit
pursuant to the following procedures:
(A) Application: Anyone seeking a conditional use permit must complete an application on a form approved by the community development director, or
his or her designee, and pay any fee required for the processing of the application as set or amended, from time to time, by resolution of the city
council. Said application shall not be deemed received unless it is complete and all fees paid.
(B) Review By The Community Development Director: The community development director, or his or her designee, shall review the application for an
administrative conditional use permit and approve, approve with conditions, or deny said application within thirty (30) days after the application is
received by the community development department. The community development director's decision shall be in writing and shall be deemed
delivered to the applicant upon the mailing of said determination by first class, United States mail, postage prepaid, to the address provided in the
application. Failure of the director to act within thirty (30) days shall not be deemed an approval.
(C) Appeal Of Determination Of The Community Development Director: If the applicant or any other person is aggrieved by the decision of the
community development director, or his or her designee, said aggrieved person may appeal the decision of the community development director, or
his or her designee, to the city council pursuant to section 11-16-6 of this chapter.
(D) Expiration: An administrative conditional use permit will expire one year after the date of issuance unless reissued by the director or his or her
designee. The director or his or her designee may require an applicant to apply for said reissuance on a form approved by the community
development director or his or her designee and pay any fee related to said issuance as set forth and amended by resolution of the city council.
(Ord. 2013-11, 12-2-2013)
Chapter 17
OFF-STREET PARKING
11-17-1: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
(A) Every building hereafter erected, reconstructed or structurally altered, shall be provided with the minimum parking space and facilities as required
by the provisions of this Chapter, which parking space shall be continuously available and maintained, with access suitable for vehicles to and from
a public street or alley. Subsequent changes of use of such buildings shall not excuse compliance with minimum parking requirements provided
herein.
(B) The provisions of this Chapter shall not be construed to require the provision of additional parking space or facilities in the case of reconstruction or
structural alteration of any of the following buildings; provided, such building was in existence at the time this Title was adopted, or during the one
(1) year period immediately prior thereto:
1. In a C or M Zone; provided, such reconstruction or alteration does not add more than five hundred square feet (500 sq. ft.) of usable floor space
to the building in the aggregate.
2. In cases of churches; provided, no addition is made to the auditorium seating capacity.
Any reconstruction permitted under this provision must be completed within one (1) year following the removal of such existing building, or within
six (6) months after the adoption of this Title, whichever is the later. (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
11-17-2: NUMBER OF SPACES REQUIRED:
(A) The number of off-street parking spaces required for different uses shall be not less than as follows:

provided. (Ord. 755, 9-20-76)
11-17-3: USES NOT SPECIFIED:
The Commission may by resolution adopted in the manner provided in Section 11-20-1 determine the parking space requirements for any use not
mentioned herein, based upon the requirements for the most nearly comparable use mentioned.
11-17-4: SIZE:
Each required off-street parking space shall have an area of not less than one hundred and seventy (170) square feet and shall have a width of not
less than eight and one-half feet (8'), exclusive of drives or aisles. (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
11-17-5: LOCATION:
Required off-street parking spaces shall be located as follows:
(A) Dwellings, including multiple family dwellings boarding and lodging houses, fraternities and sororities, shall have all required parking facilities on
the same lot or building site. The required parking spaces shall be located behind the front, rear and side yard building setbacks of applicable
residential zones and behind landscape setbacks of applicable commercial and industrial zones.
(B) For all other uses, the required parking spaces shall be not more than six hundred feet (600') from the building or use served thereby, unless on
the same lot or building site. The required parking spaces shall be located behind the front, rear and side yard setbacks of applicable residential
zones and behind landscape setbacks of applicable commercial and industrial zones.
(C) Distance as herein mentioned shall refer to the distance measured from the nearest point of the parking facility to the nearest access to the
building or use, along a pedestrian way available to the public or persons to be served by the facility. (Ord. 886, 5-5-86)
11-17-6: DESIGN AND IMPROVEMENTS:
(A) Access: Each parking lot or area shall be provided with safe exits and entrances to and from a public street or way through suitable drives or
aisles. Access to a parking space from aisles or drives shall be such as not to interfere with the use of other required parking spaces on the lot.
(Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
(B) Parking Lot Surfacing: All parking lots or areas shall be paved with asphaltic or portland cement concrete paving and maintained so as to be free
from the accumulation of dust and debris. (Ord. 820, 12-15-80)
(C) Fences: Where any parking lot or area abuts property in any R Zone, it shall be separated from such property by a screen fence or wall of not less
than six feet (6') high; provided, that such screen fence or wall shall be forty two inches (42") high from the front property line to a depth equal to
the required front yard on the abutting R Zone property.
(D) Barriers: At all points along streets or sidewalks, excepting points of access to the parking lot or area, a concrete curb or timber barrier not less
than six inches (6") high shall be installed and maintained.
(E) Lights: Where any parking lot or area abuts property in any R Zone, no lights or reflectors erected on the parking lot shall be permitted to shed light
onto the property in the R Zone.
(F) Exception: All of the requirements of this Section shall apply to any parking lot or area, excepting parking spaces or areas used exclusively by the
occupants of dwellings, their guests and employees, including multiple-family dwellings, boarding and lodging houses, fraternities and sororities,
where located on the same lot or building site. (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
(G) Handicapped and Small Car Parking Stalls:
1. There shall be at least one parking space provided for physically handicapped persons for every fifty (50) parking spaces or fraction thereof, in
the first two hundred (200) parking spaces, beginning with a minimum of forty (40) stalls, except for medical equipment buildings. After the first
two hundred (200) spaces, one additional parking space shall be provided for every one hundred (100) spaces up to two thousand (2,000)
spaces, and one space shall be provided for every four hundred (400) parking spaces exceeding two thousand (2,000). Medical offices, medical
laboratories and medical equipment buildings shall provide at least one parking space for the physically handicapped.
2. Handicapped stalls may be offset with small car parking stalls at seven and one-half feet (7') in width, and sixteen feet (16') in length not to
exceed three (3) for each handicapped stall. Stalls for handicapped shall be designed to function at thirteen feet (13') in width. In no event shall
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 373/436
small car stalls exceed twenty percent (20%) of the parking area.
3. All parking spaces for the physically handicapped shall be located adjacent to the primary entrance of buildings or structures (or access ramps
as necessary) or in strategic areas.
4. There shall be a sign provided at the entrance to parking lots containing over two hundred (200) parking stalls, directing handicapped persons to
stall locations. The handicapped and "small car only" stalls shall be posted conspicuously on a pole measuring seven feet (7') in height from
adjacent grade to bottom of sign.
5. There shall be at least one access ramp provided for every two hundred feet (200') of building access walkways leading to the primary entrance
points, with the distance between ramps not to exceed two hundred feet (200') or portion thereof.
6. All access ramps shall be at least four feet (4') wide and not exceed a grade on one foot (1') in fifteen (15). All ramps shall have a nonslip
surface.
7. Requirements for handicapped parking shall be complied with in all new parking facilities. (Ord. 819, 10-6-80)
11-17-7: PLANS FOR PARKING AREA; SUBMISSION AND APPROVAL:
(A) The proposed plan of any required parking space or area shall be submitted to the official authorized to issue building and use permits at the time
of application for the permit for the building or use to be served by such parking area, which plan shall show the size, location, design and
improvements thereof, all of which shall comply with the minimum requirements of this Chapter.
(B) Unless the official shall find that such plan for the required parking space or area as submitted complies with the minimum requirements of this
Chapter, he shall not issue the building or use permit; provided, that if he finds that the plan thus complies, he shall endorse his approval thereon
and shall file the same with the copy of the building or use permit.
(C) In determining whether the plan so complies with the provisions of this Chapter, the official shall determine, in addition to other matters herein
required, whether the proposed points of exit and entrance to and from public ways are safe.
(D) The points of exit and entrance to and from public ways shall not thereafter be changed from those shown in the plan, unless with the written
approval of the official or his lawful successor.
(E) The parking lot or area shall be constructed in accordance with the approved plan as filed, and shall thereafter be permanently maintained so as to
comply with the minimum requirement of this Title as in effect at the time of approval of the plan. (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
Chapter 18
REQUIRED LOADING SPACE
11-18-1: OFF-STREET LOADING FACILITIES:
(A) For every building hereafter erected or reconstructed or structurally altered which is to be occupied by manufacturing, storage, warehouse, retail
store, wholesale store, market, hotel, hospital, mortuary, laundry, dry cleaning, or other uses similarly requiring the receipt or distribution by
vehicles of materials and merchandise, off-street loading areas shall be provided as follows:
1. Commercial Uses: The number of loading spaces shall be determined by the Planning Director, subject to appeal to the Planning Commission.
2. Industrial Uses:
10,000 to 24,999 square feet gross floor area 1 loading space
25,000 to 49,000 square feet gross floor area 2 loading spaces
For each additional 50,000 square feet of
gross floor area or major fraction thereof
1 loading space
(B) Each loading space shall be not less than twelve feet (12') in width, forty feet (40') in length, and with an overhead clearance of fourteen feet (14').
(C) Such space may not be located in any part of any required front or side yard. (Ord. 871, 8-6-84)
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 374/436
Chapter 19
NONCONFORMING BUILDINGS AND USES
11-19-1: NONCONFORMING BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES:
(A) No nonconforming building or structure shall be structurally altered or enlarged, except as follows:
1. Where required by this Code or Statute, or in order to make the building or structure conform.
2. Any building or structure which is nonconforming solely by reason of yard or height requirements may be structurally altered or enlarged;
provided, that all alterations or additions shall comply with the yard and height requirements of the zone; and further provided, that the entire
building or structure so altered or enlarged complies with all other requirements of the Title other than yard and height.
(B) If a nonconforming building or structure is removed, every future use of such premises shall be in conformity with the provisions of this Title.
(C) A nonconforming building or structure in a C or M Zone may be continued, subject to the preceding provision.
(D) In all R Zones every nonconforming building, or structure, other than a residential building, designed or intended for use not permitted in such zone
shall be completely removed or altered to structurally conform to the uses permitted in such zone within a time determined by the Commission,
provided:
1. Such time for removal or alteration may not be fixed for a date before the expiration of the normal life of the building or structure as found by the
Commission.
2. In no event may the normal life of the building or structure be fixed at less than forty (40) years from its original construction.
3. No such order shall require the removal or alteration of the building or structure sooner than ten (10) years from the time such order is made.
4. Within ten (10) days after the making of such order, the Commission shall give notice thereof to the owner of record of the building or structure
by causing a copy of the order to be personally served on the owner or mailed to the owner by registered or certified mail addressed to his
residence, or if his residence is unknown, then to his address as shown by the records of the Tax Collector of the City, and by causing a copy of
the order to be recorded in the office of the County Recorder.
5. Not less than sixty (60) days and not more than ninety (90) days before the time fixed for removal or alteration, the officer in charge of issuance
of use permits shall give the owner of record of such building or structure written notice thereof in the manner above mentioned, and shall give
the occupants of such building notice thereof by leaving with any of the occupants of said building or posting on said building in a conspicuous
place, such notice.
6. Such notice may be given after the time so fixed, but in no case shall such a building or structure be required to be so removed or altered
without at least sixty (60) days' notice being given.
(E) Proceedings for determination of time for removal or alteration of such nonconforming buildings or structures in R Zones, as mentioned in
subsection (D) may be initiated and shall be set for hearing, noticed, heard and determined in substantially the same manner as provided in the
following named provisions relating to amendment; provided, that all references therein to amendments shall be deemed to refer to the
proceedings relating to such determination. The provisions are as follows:
Section 11-21-1; subsection 11-21-2(C); Section 11-21-3; subsections 11-21-4(A), (B), (C), (D) and (F).
(F) All decisions of the Commission in proceedings for such determination may be appealed and reviewed in substantially the same manner as
provided in the following named provisions relating to appeals from decisions of the Board of Zoning Adjustment; provided, that all references
therein to the Board of Zoning Adjustment shall be deemed to refer to the Commission. The provisions are as follows:
Section 11-23-7; subsections 11-23-8(A) and (B). (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
11-19-2: NONCONFORMING USES OF BUILDINGS:
(A) The nonconforming use of a building existing at the time this Title became effective may be continued, provided:
1. The nonconforming use of a building may be expanded or extended throughout the building. A nonconforming use of a nonconforming building
may be changed to another use of the same or more restricted classification.
2. Conforming Buildings: A nonconforming use of a conforming building shall not be expanded or extended into any other portion of the conforming
building, and if such nonconforming use is discontinued, any future use of such building shall be in conformity with the provisions of this Title.
(B) A building which is nonconforming solely by reason that it does not conform with one or more height, yard or area regulations shall, for the
purposes of this Section be deemed to be a conforming building.
(C) Notwithstanding any other provision of this Chapter, a use which is one which becomes nonconforming by virtue of an amendment of this Title,
change in the use or otherwise, for failure or lack of approval of a required permit or site plan review, shall be discontinued within two (2) years of
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 375/436
the date the use becomes nonconforming or upon a date provided for by general law, whichever is earlier. The nonconforming use shall cease to
exist if the required permits and/or site plan reviews are not timely obtained. (Ord. 875, 3-1-85)
11-19-3: NONCONFORMING BUILDINGS AND USES PARTIALLY DESTROYED BY CASUALTY:
(A) Subject to all other regulations of this Chapter, a nonconforming building or structure destroyed to the extent of not more than seventy five percent
(75%) of its reasonable value by fire, explosion or other casualty or by act of God, or the public enemy, may be restored and the occupancy or use
of the building or structure or part thereof which existed at the time of such partial destruction may be continued. The time for removal or alteration
of the restored building or structure as mentioned in subsection 11-19-1(D) shall nevertheless be the same as if such building or structure had not
been thus restored.
(B) If a nonconforming building or structure is so destroyed to an extent of more than seventy five percent (75%) of its reasonable value, the same
may not be restored, and may not be occupied and used, except in conformity with this Title.
11-19-4: NONCONFORMING USE OF LAND:
(A) The nonconforming use of land where no structure (excepting fences) thereon is employed in connection with such use, and nonconforming signs
or billboards, existing at the time this Title became effective, or which thereafter becomes subject to the provisions of this Title, may be continued
for a period of not more than three (3) years thereafter.
(B) If a structure is employed in connection with a nonconforming use of land, and is removed, or destroyed to the extent of more than seventy five
percent (75%) of its reasonable value by any cause, or the nonconforming use of the structure is discontinued, the nonconforming use of such land
may be continued for a period of not more than three (3) years after the date of such removal, destruction or discontinuance.
(C) No nonconforming use of land shall in any way be expanded or extended either on the same or adjoining property, or changed, except to a
conforming use. (Ord. 533, 6-5-1961)
(D) If a nonconforming use of land, including, but not limited to, agricultural land use, which is permitted to be continued under any of the provisions of
this section, is discontinued for one year, any future use of such land shall conform to the provisions of this title. (Ord. 2003-2, 2-18-2003)
11-19-5: EFFECT OF ZONE CHANGES:
(A) All of the provisions of this chapter shall apply to buildings, land and uses which hereafter become nonconforming due to any amendment of this
title.
(B) If a zone is established by this title or is hereafter changed, so as to cause any boundary thereof to be located closer than the specified minimum
distance to a use which under the provisions of this title may not be established within such minimum distance from the zone, then such use shall
be deemed to be a nonconforming use. (Ord. 533, 6-5-1961)
Chapter 20
GENERAL PROVISIONS AND EXCEPTIONS
11-20-1: CLARIFICATION OF AMBIGUITY OR INTERPRETATION:
In the event of need for any clarification or interpretation, the commission shall ascertain all pertinent facts and by resolution shall set forth its findings.
The resolution shall be transmitted to the council, and if approved by the council, the clarification or interpretation shall govern until modified by
resolution adopted in like manner or by appropriate amendment of this title.
The foregoing shall apply to the following cases:
(A) If ambiguity arises concerning the appropriate classification of a particular use within the meaning and intent of this title.
(B) If ambiguity exists with reference to matters of height, yard, area, and other requirements.
(C) If uncertainty exists with reference to a zone boundary.
(D) If an unforeseen condition arises or technological changes have been introduced.
(E) If ambiguity or uncertainty arises as to the meaning of any word or provision contained in this title. (Ord. 533, 6-5-1961)
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 376/436
11-20-2: POTENTIAL ZONE INDICATION:
The commission may by resolution designate the potential zone classification of any area or zone whenever the area or zone is found to be suitable
for a different zone classification but where it is impracticable to presently so classify the same or fix the exact boundaries thereof. Such designation of
potential use classification shall serve only as a guide to the Commission and the Council with respect to future action relating to the area or zone, and
shall have no other effect. The approximate area subject to such potential zone classification shall be shown upon the Zone Map enclosed within a
heavy dashed line with the appropriate zone symbol therein enclosed within a circle.
11-20-3: PUBLIC UTILITY LINES AND MAINS:
(A) The provisions of this Title shall not be construed to limit installation or maintenance of public utility pole lines, pipes, and mains, or require any use
permit therefor.
(B) The provisions of this Title shall not be construed to limit the installation or maintenance of any public utility transmission line or tower, excepting
that prior to the acquisition of rights-of-way therefor, the Planning Commission shall be informed in writing of the proposed route and location
thereof.
11-20-4: HEIGHT:
(A) Height of buildings shall be measured along the vertical distance from the average level of the highest and lowest point of that portion of the lot
covered by the building to the highest point of the roof.
(B) One-family dwellings in the R-1 Zone and R-2 Zone may be increased in height by not more than ten feet (10') when two (2) side yards of not less
than fifteen feet (15') each are provided.
(C) Churches and schools in the R-2 Zone may be erected to a height of not more than seventy-five feet (75'); provided, that such buildings shall in
any case comply with the provisions of Section 11-20-6.
(D) Penthouses or roof structures for the housing of elevators, stairways, tanks, ventilating fans or similar equipment required to operate and maintain
buildings, and fire or parapet walls, skylights, towers, roof signs, flagpoles, chimneys, smokestacks, television and radio masts, or similar structures
may be erected above the height limit but shall not be a allowed for the purpose of providing additional floor space.
11-20-5: AREA:
(A) No lot area shall be so reduced or diminished or divided so that the yards, open space, buildable area or lot area shall be smaller than prescribed
by this Title; nor shall the density of population be increased in any manner except in conformity with this Title.
(B) No yard or other open space provided around any building for the purpose of complying with the provisions of this Title shall be considered as
providing the required yard, open space or buildable area for any other building; provided further, that no yard or open space on any adjoining lot
shall be considered as providing a yard, open space or buildable area or lot area on any other lot.
(C) Two (2) or more abutting lots may be combined and used as though a single lot, in which case such combination of lots shall be deemed to be a
single lot for all purposes of this Title, so long as there shall exist on any part thereof any structure or improvement which depends for compliance
with the Title upon the same being so treated as a single lot.
(D) A lot may be divided into parts; provided, that each part is equal to or exceeds the minimum lot area requirements of this Title, and so long as such
parts are used as though separate lots, they shall be deemed to be lots under all provisions of this Title.
(E) Every required front, side or rear yard shall be open and unobstructed from the ground to the sky, except as otherwise provided in this Chapter.
11-20-6: INSTITUTIONAL BUILDINGS; ADDITIONAL YARD REQUIREMENTS:
Any building erected, altered or used for school or church purposes, or as an institutional building as mentioned in Section 11-5-2, shall be located at
least fifteen feet (15') from every lot line or any property included in any R Zone, notwithstanding any lesser requirement in the zone where located;
provided, such building shall not be required to be located more than five feet (5') from any lot line adjacent to any alley. With respect to the accessory
buildings, the Commission shall have authority to waive the foregoing requirements for good cause.
11-20-7: TWO-FAMILY DWELLINGS; ORIENTED TO SIDE YARDS:
One (1) or more two-family or three-family dwellings, multiple-family dwellings, or group houses, not exceeding thirty-five feet (35') in height may be
oriented as to front or rear upon either side yard, in which case the following regulations shall apply:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 377/436
(A) When such dwellings rear upon a side yard, the required width of the side yard shall be increased by one foot (1') for each such dwelling unit, but
the increase need not exceed five feet (5'). Porches and steps mentioned in Section 11-20-11 shall be permitted; provided, not less than five feet
(5') of the width of the required side yard shall be completely free of structures.
(B) When the dwellings front upon a side yard, the required width of the side yard shall be not less than ten feet (10'). Porches and steps mentioned in
Section 11-20-11 shall be permitted.
(C) All other requirements of this Title, including front, side and rear yards, buildable area and lot area shall apply.
11-20-8: ACCESSORY BUILDINGS:
(A) Space Between Accessory Buildings and Dwellings: The space between a dwelling and any accessory building on the same lot, when not joined
by a common wall, shall be a minimum distance of twice the width of the required interior side yard, or eight feet (8'), whichever is greater.
(B) Accessory Buildings in Required Side Yards: A non-dwelling building may be located in a required side yard area on any part of the rear one-third
(1/3) of a lot, subject to the limitations of subsection (C) following.
(C) Accessory Buildings in Required Rear Yards: Accessory buildings may be located in a portion of the required rear yard area in R Zones, provided:
1. Such building may occupy not more than twenty percent (20%) of the length of the required rear yard, measured between side lot lines.
2. Such building may not be more than eighteen feet (18') in height.
3. No such building may occupy any part of the required rear yard of a reversed corner lot.
11-20-9: THROUGH LOTS:
On a through lot, a front yard shall be provided on each street frontage. Each such front yard shall have a minimum depth of not less than the required
front yard of the adjacent lot or the average of the required front yards of the lots adjoining on either side. The front yards shall be subject to all
provisions of this Title, including provisions for reduction of requirements mentioned in Section 11-20-15.
11-20-10: OUTSIDE STAIRWAYS AND BALCONIES; FIRE ESCAPES:
(A) Stairways, stair landings and balconies may extend into the required front yard not more than three feet (3'); provided, that all such structures shall
be open, unenclosed and without roofs, except for lattice type guard railings. Structural supports for stairways and landings may be enclosed.
(B) Fire escapes, required by law, ordinance or regulations of a public agency, may project into any front, side or rear yard not more than four feet (4').
(C) Depressed ramps or stairways and their supporting structures, designed to permit access to parts of buildings below average ground level, may
extend into any required yard not more than forty two inches (42").
11-20-11: PORCHES, PLATFORMS AND LANDINGS:
(A) Uncovered porches, platforms or landing places which do not extend above the level of the first floor of the building, may extend into required
yards as follows:
1. Into front yards not more than six feet (6').
2. Into side yards and rear yards not more than five feet (5').
3. Lattice type guard railings or walls, of not more than thirty six inches (36") in height, may be installed or constructed on such structures. (Ord.
533, 6-5-61)
11-20-12: EAVES; SILLS:
Eaves, sills, cornices, beltcourses, buttresses or similar architectural features, fireplaces not exceeding eight feet (8') in width, and planting boxes, may
extend or project into a required side yard or rear yard not more than four inches (4") for each one foot (1') of the width of the required yard, and may
extend or project into the required front yard not more than thirty six inches (36"). (Ord. 612, 1-17-66)
11-20-13: TREES; PLANTS:
Trees, plants, shrubs or flowers may be maintained in any required front, side or rear yard, provided that hedges shall comply with Section 11-20-14.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 378/436
(Ord. 802, 5-7-79)
11-20-14: FENCES; WALLS; HEDGES:
(A) Six foot (6') high fences, walls and shrubs shall be permitted anywhere except within the required front yard and when a private driveway accesses
a public right of way through the side yard, then the provisions of subsections B and F of 11-20-14 shall apply. (Ord. 93-3, 6-21-93)
(B) Open fences and shrubs not exceeding forty eight inches (48") in height or solid walls and fences not exceeding forty two inches (42") in height
shall be permitted in the required front yard. (Ord. 93-3, 6-21-93)
(C) Open or lattice type fences, not exceeding six feet (6') in height, may be maintained on any part of elementary or high school sites.
(D) Height Requirements For Gates: Fence, wall or hedge, as used in this Section, shall be deemed to include gates, which shall be subject to the
height requirements. (Ord. 533, 6-5-1961)
(E) Noise Abatement: A six foot (6') high solid masonry fence wall constructed in accordance with City Standard Drawing No. 0-19 shall be provided by
the developer at the time of construction, for the purpose of noise abatement, in the following locations:
1. At the interface between areas zoned C, M or R-O and any adjacent residential area.
2. At the interface between a residential subdivision and an adjacent major traffic artery which now has, or is estimated by the City Engineer to
have, within ten (10) years from the date of last review, an average daily traffic count of seven thousand five hundred (7,500) vehicles.
3. At the interface between the boundary of a residential subdivision and any portion of a buffer zone six hundred feet (600') in width on either side
of and parallel to the center line of the Freeway 99.
A developer may apply to the Planning Commission for a modification of the requirements of this Section on the grounds that an alternative
design would be more functional and aesthetically pleasing. In such cases the developer shall submit an application for exemption to the
Commission, and such application shall contain detailed drawings and specifications of the proposed construction as a part of the submittal. The
developer shall be required to supply data which would clearly show that the residential area would not be subjected to a noise level that would
be less acceptable than the resultant noise level if a solid masonry fence wall was constructed. (Ord. 802, 5-7-1979)
(F) Fences And Shrubs, Height Requirements: All fences and shrubs over forty two inches (42") in height shall be set back a minimum of ten feet (10')
from the street side property line when a private driveway accesses a public right of way through the side yard. Fences and shrubs not exceeding
forty two inches (42") shall be permitted in the required setback area. (Ord. 93-3, 6-21-1993)
(G) Barbed Wire, Concertina Wire, Razor Wire And Similar Security Fencing: The following regulations shall govern the installation of all new security
fencing:
1. Barbed Wire: Up to four (4) single strands of barbed wire may be used at the top of any fence permitted in the commercial and industrial
districts.
(a) The addition of barbed wire shall not be included in the height of the fence.
(b) Barbed wire shall not be permitted in, or contiguous to, any property zoned or designated by the Selma General Plan for residential uses.
2. Concertina Or Razor Wire: Concertina or razor wire may be used in an area zoned for industrial use only.
(a) The conditions of subsection (G)1(b) of this Section shall also apply to razor wire with the further restriction that the term contiguous shall be
inclusive of areas where, except for an intervening street, the properties would be contiguous.
(b) Any security fencing incorporating concertina or razor wire, which was constructed, either within or contiguous to a residential area, with
permits or in accordance with the City's rules, regulations and policies in effect at the time of construction, shall be considered a legal
nonconforming installation. All legal nonconforming installations installed prior to the effective date of this Chapter shall be removed not later
than two (2) years from such effective date.
3. Hold Harmless Agreement: Prior to issuance of any permit to install razor or concertina wire in an industrial district, the property owner must sign
a written hold harmless agreement, in a form satisfactory to the City Attorney. The agreement shall release and indemnify the City in the event of
liability, loss, costs and damages, including, but not limited to, personal injury, death or property damage, arising directly or indirectly out of the
use of the special security topping. (Ord. 98-3, 6-1-1998)
11-20-15: REDUCTION OF FRONT YARD REQUIREMENTS; WHEN PERMITTED:
Where more than sixty percent (60%) of the portion of the lineal frontage of lots improved with buildings within any block is comprised of lots with less
than the minimum front yard requirement, then the minimum front yard requirement for such block shall be reduced to the average of the actual front
yards of all of the lots in the block improved with buildings, counting those which have front yards of greater depth than the minimum requirement as
having the minimum requirement. (Ord. 533, 6-5-1961)
11-20-16: OFF SITE SALES PROHIBITED:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 379/436
In all zone districts, the off site sale of new and used autos and automobiles, and recreational vehicles, motorized or nonmotorized, retail or wholesale
is prohibited. Sales must be conducted only at the permanent property address in the city of Selma listed for the dealership on its department of motor
vehicles dealer license. (Ord. 2002-17, 10-21-2002)
11-20-17: LIMITATIONS ON USES:
The following regulations shall be limitations on, and be applicable to, all uses in zones R-1, R-1-9, R-1-12, R-2-A, R-2, R-3-A, R-3, R-TP, R-O, R-A,
and zones P-1 and C-1 where they are used for residential purposes.
(A) Vehicles:
1. Purpose: The purpose of this section is to maintain attractive streets and neighborhoods in the city, to limit the use of residential neighborhoods
for healthful living purposes, and to allow for citations to be issued by the police department for zoning enforcement activity related to unlawful
repair, storage, assembly, and dismantling of vehicles, primarily within front yard setback areas of residential lots.
2. Repair, Dismantling Or Storage Of Vehicles Prohibited: No persons shall assemble, repair, dismantle or store any vehicle, (hereinafter referred to
as an inoperable vehicle), other than as herein provided, on any part of an "R" zoned lot, unless such inoperable vehicle is:
(a) Within an enclosed building; or
(b) In an open area which is completely enclosed by view obscuring walls or solid fences, not less than six feet (6') in height, or by the exterior
walls of a building or buildings.
(c) A vehicle, as defined in this section, may be temporarily stored in driveway areas and in residential areas of the city, provided that inoperable
or disabled vehicles may be parked for not more than seven (7) days in any one month, in the front yard for purposes of loading and
unloading, if such parking may be accomplished in a manner that does not encroach upon the public right of way or violate any other
provisions of this code relating to parking. No vehicle, while inoperable in a residential area, shall be used for sleeping or habitation.
3. Exception: Provided, that the prohibition of uses imposed by subsection (A)2 of this section shall not be deemed to apply to the occasional and
incidental assembly or repair of vehicles owned by the person in possession of the premises on which such takes place; provided that a disabled
vehicle which is being repaired or assembled, shall not be stored except as provided in subsection (A)2 of this section for a period not longer
than seven (7) consecutive days within any thirty (30) day period.
4. Vehicles Defined: "Vehicles", as defined in this section, shall be deemed to include any vehicle, as defined by the state, designed to be pulled or
driven upon a public street, except that recreation type vehicles are specifically excluded from this definition and are not deemed to be a public
nuisance. (Ord. 860, 9-19-1983)
Chapter 20.1
SITE PLAN REVIEW
11-20.1-1: PURPOSES; APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The purposes of site plan review are to enable the planning official to make a finding that the proposed development is in conformity with the intent
and provisions of this Chapter and to guide the Building Department in the issuance of building permits. The provisions of this Chapter shall apply to
the following uses:
(A) Any use listed within a particular zoning district as a permitted or conditional use subject to site plan review.
(B) Permitted and conditional uses within the P, C and M Districts.
(C) Conditional uses where site plan review is made a condition of approval.
11-20.1-2: SITE PLAN:
(A) Information. The applicant shall submit three (3) prints of the site plan to the planning official. The site plan shall be drawn to scale and shall
indicate clearly and with full dimensions the following information:
1. The lot dimensions;
2. All buildings and structures and their location, elevation, size, height, and proposed use;
3. The yards and spaces between buildings;
4. Walls and fences and their location, height and materials;
5. Off-street parking, including the location, number of spaces, dimensions of the parking area, and internal circulation patterns;
6. Access, pedestrian, vehicular, and service, points of ingress and egress, and internal circulation;
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 380/436
7. Signs and their location, size and height;
8. Loading, including the location, dimensions, number of spaces, and internal circulation;
9. Lighting, including the location, general nature, and hooding devices, if any; (Ord. 766, 4-4-77)
10. Street dedications and improvements, as provided in Section 11-20.1-20(G); (Ord. 790, 6-19-78)
11. Drainage;
12. Landscaping, including the location and type;
13. Fire prevention equipment and measures, including type and location;
14. Such other data as may be required to permit the planning official to make the required findings.
(B) Findings. Within ten (10) working days after submission of a complete site plan, the planning official shall approve, approve with such conditions as
set forth in Section 11-20.1-2(B)5 of this Title or disapprove the site plan. In approving the site plan, the planning official shall find that:
1. All the applicable provisions of this Chapter are complied with;
2. The following are so arranged that traffic congestion is avoided and pedestrian and vehicular safety and welfare are protected and there will be
no adverse effect on surrounding property;
(a) Facilities, improvements, and utilities;
(b) Vehicular ingress, egress, and internal circulation;
(c) Setbacks;
(d) Height of buildings;
(e) Location of service use areas;
(f) Walls; and
(g) Landscaping.
3. The proposed lighting is so arranged as to deflect the light away from adjoining properties; and
4. The proposed signs will not by size, location or lighting interfere with traffic or limit visibility.
5. That any conditions of approval are deemed necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare. Conditions may include the following:
(a) Special yards, spaces and buffers.
(b) Fences and walls.
(c) Enclosure of storage areas and limitation on out of door display of merchandise.
(d) Grading, surfacing and drainage specifications.
(e) Regulation of points of vehicular ingress and egress.
(f) Regulation of signs.
(g) Requiring landscaping and maintenance thereof.
(h) Requiring maintenance of grounds.
(i) Requiring fire prevention equipment and measures.
(j) Regulation of noise, vibration, odors, electrical discharge or interference.
(k) Regulation of lighting. (Ord. 766, 4-4-77)
(l) Requiring street dedication and improvements subject to the provisions of Section 11-20.1-2(G). (Ord. 790, 6-19-78)
(m) And such other conditions as could make possible the development of the City in an orderly and efficient manner and in conformity with the
intent and purposes set forth in this Section.
In making such findings, the planning official shall consult with other City personnel as appropriate to assure that approvals will be consistent
with established legislative policies relating to traffic safety, street dedications, street improvements, and public safety.
(C) Appeal to the Planning Commission. The applicant or any aggrieved person may appeal, in writing, setting forth the reason for such appeal to the
Planning Commission. Such appeal shall be filed with the Planning Commission within ten (10) days after the mailing of the notice of such
decision. The appeal shall be placed on the agenda of the Planning Commission's next regular meeting after the planning official's decision;
provided, however, if the planning official's decision occurs within ten (10) days of the next regular meeting of the Planning Commission, the appeal
shall be placed on the agenda of the Planning Commission's second regular meeting following the decision of the planning official. The Planning
Commission shall review the site plan and shall by resolution approve, approve with conditions, or disapprove, based on the findings set forth in
subsection (B) of this Section. The decision of the Planning Commission shall be final unless appealed to the Council.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 381/436
(D) Appeals to the Council. The applicant or any aggrieved person may appeal, in writing, setting forth the reason for such appeal to the Council. Such
appeal shall be filed with the City Clerk within ten (10) days after the Planning Commission's decision. The appeal shall be placed on the agenda of
the Council's next regular meeting after the appeal is filed; provided, however, that if the appeal is filed within ten (10) days of the next regular
meeting of the Council, the appeal shall be placed on the agenda of the Council's second regular meeting following the decision of the Planning
Commission. The Council shall review the site plan and shall by resolution approve, approve with conditions, or disapprove, based on the findings
set forth in subsection (B) of this Section. The decision of the Council shall be final.
(E) Formal approval. The approved site plan, with any conditions shown thereon or attached thereto, shall be dated and signed by the planning official.
One copy of the site plan and conditions shall be mailed to the applicant.
(F) Revisions. Revisions by the applicant to an approved site plan shall be made pursuant to the procedure set forth in this Section. (Ord. 766, 4-4-77)
(G) Required Street Dedications and Improvements: Because of changes that may occur in an area due to increases in vehicular traffic generated by
facilities requiring site plan review, and upon the principle that such developments should be required to provide street dedications and
improvements as near as practicable in proportion to such increased vehicular traffic, but should not be required to provide such street facilities for
nonrelated traffic, the dedications and improvements specified in subsections 1, 2, 3 and 4 below, may be deemed necessary by the City Engineer
and may be required as a condition to approval of any site plan. The City Engineer may require that a fee be paid in lieu of constructing the
improvements required in subsections 2, 3 and 4 below, if the City Engineer determines that it would be in the public interest to defer construction
of said improvements. The amount of the fee shall be determined by the City Engineer and shall be equal to the cost of the improvements that
would have otherwise been required.
1. The dedication of all land necessary to widen an existing street right of way or new street made necessary by a development to its ultimate
planned right of way as established by any adopted general, specific or precise plan or by the City's improvement standards may be required.
2. Where a development borders a new street, the dedication of which was required pursuant to subsection 1, above, or an existing street right of
way which is not developed in accordance with the City's improvement standards, the improvement of the right of way of said street to City
standards for a width of thirty feet (30') as measured from the ultimate right-of-way line of the street abutting the development may be required.
The required improvements may include, but are not limited to, curbs, gutters and sidewalks, drainage facilities, street trees, street signs, street
lights, required utilities, street grading and paving.
3. Where a development is traversed by a new street, the dedication of which was required pursuant to subsection 1, above, or an existing street
right of way which is not developed in accordance with the City's improvement standards, the improvement of the right of way of said street to
City standards for a width of sixty feet (60') may be required. If the right of way of the street exceeds sixty feet (60'), the City Engineer shall
determine the section(s) of the right of way to be improved. The required improvements may include, but are not limited to, curbs, gutters and
sidewalks, drainage facilities, street trees, street signs, street lights, required utilities, street grading and paving.
4. Where a development borders a new frontage road, the dedication of which was required pursuant to subsection 1, above, or an existing
frontage road right of way which is not developed in accordance with the City's improvement standards, the improvement of the entire right of
way of said street abutting the development may be required.
(H) Building Permits: Before a building permit shall be issued for any building or structure that is subject to site plan review, the City Building inspector
shall determine that:
1. The proposed building is in conformity with the site plan and conditions approved by the Planning Official, and
2. All required dedications have been recorded; and
3. A letter has been furnished by the applicant from all appropriate utilities, that all necessary utilities will be installed and that the utility companies
will conform to all City ordinances.
(I) Occupancy: Before any building or structure that is subject to site plan review shall be occupied, the City Building Inspector shall determine that all
required on-site (outside the City right of way) and the City Engineer shall determine that all required off-site (within the City right of way)
improvements shall have either been completed prior to occupancy of the premises or if not completed, the permittee shall have entered into an
agreement with the City to complete said work within six (6) months from the date of occupancy. The City Building Inspector in the case of on-site
improvements and the City Engineer in the case of off-site improvements may extend the completion date for one additional six (6) month period
upon written request of the permittee, upon a showing of good cause therefor. Such an agreement shall be secured either by cash deposited with
the City, cash deposited in irrevocable escrow approved by the City Attorney, or other financial security approved by the City Attorney as the
equivalent thereof. Such security shall be in the amount of one hundred percent (100%) of the estimated cost of completion as determined by the
City Building Inspector in the case of on-site improvements and the City Engineer in the case of off-site improvements. In the event such work is
not completed within the period provided, or any extension thereof, the City shall be authorized to take all necessary action to enforce the
agreement, including the use of said security to cause the completion of all required improvements. Monies deposited with the City or in escrow
may be partially released to the depositor by the City Building Inspector in the case of on-site improvements and the City Engineer in the case of
off-site improvements during the progress of the work, so long as the same ratio of security is maintained on the deposit to secure all uncompleted
work. (Ord. 790, 6-19-78)
Chapter 21
AMENDMENTS
11-21-1: INITIATION OF AMENDMENTS TO TITLE; HEARING:
(A) Amendment of this Title may be initiated in one (1) of the following manners:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 382/436
1. By verified application of any interested person.
2. By resolution of intention adopted by the Commission.
3. By resolution of intention adopted by the Council, which resolution shall be referred to the Commission for hearing.
(B) Upon filing with or adoption by the Commission of any such application or resolution, the Commission shall hold a public hearing thereon, and such
additional public hearings as the Commission deems necessary.
(C) The Commission or its Secretary shall set the time and place for the hearing, which shall be held within forty (40) days following the filing with the
Commission of the application or resolution.
11-21-2: NOTICE OF HEARINGS:
(A) For the purpose of this Section, any amendment of this Title which is for the purpose of changing particular property from one (1) zone to another
or changing the boundary of any particular zone shall be referred to as a "zone change amendment," and all other amendments to this Title shall
be referred to as a "general amendment."
(B) Notice of General Amendment: Notice of the time and place of any public hearing on the matter of any general amendment to this Title shall be
given by the Commission or its Secretary by at least one (1) publication in a newspaper of general circulation published in the City, at least ten (10)
days before the hearing and by such other means as the Commission may deem necessary.
(C) Notice of Zone Change Amendment:
1. Notice of the time and place of any public hearing on the matter of a zone change amendment to this Title shall be given by the Commission or
its Secretary by mailing in the United States mail a written notice thereof, not less than ten (10) days prior to the hearing, to every person whose
name and address appears on the latest available assessment roll as an owner of any property within the territory covered by such proposed
change and within three hundred feet (300') of the outer boundaries thereof.
2. The notice shall also be given by posting a written notice on the territory covered by the proposed change, at a point designated by the
Commission or its Secretary, not less than ten (10) days prior to the hearing, and such additional notices as the Commission may determine;
provided, however, that failure to so post or maintain any such notice shall not be construed so as to invalidate or void any subsequent
proceedings.
3. The notice shall also be given by publication as provided in Subsection (B) of this Section.
11-21-3: HEARINGS BY PLANNING COMMISSION ON AMENDMENTS:
(A) The public hearing shall be held at the time and place for which set and noticed.
(B) Continuance: Any hearing may be continued by the majority of members present at any hearing, who may fix a time and place to which such
hearing may be continued, even in the absence of a quorum, in which case the presiding officer at such hearing shall publicly announce prior to the
conclusion of the hearing the time and place to which the hearing is to be continued, and no further notice shall be required.
(C) Quorum: A majority in number of the total voting membership of the Commission shall constitute a legal quorum for the purposes of conducting
such a hearing.
(D) Voting: The recommendation of any amendment of this Title shall be by resolution of the Commission, carried by the affirmative votes of not less
than a majority of its total voting membership.
(E) Rules of Procedure: The Commission shall have authority to establish any reasonable rules of procedure for the conduct of such hearings. The
Commission may require any person who is to testify before it to be placed under oath, in which case the member presiding at the hearing shall be
empowered to administer such oath.
(F) Investigations: The Commission may cause such investigations to be made as it deems necessary and in the public interest in any matter to be
heard by it. The investigation may be made by a committee of one (1) or more members of the investigation or by members of its staff or its agents
or employees. The facts established by such investigation shall be submitted to the Commission either in writing, to be filed with the records of the
matter, or in testimony before the Commission, and may be considered by the Commission in making its decision.
(G) Record of Hearing: The Commission shall cause a written summary of all pertinent testimony heard at the public hearing, together with a record of
the names and addresses of all persons testifying, to be prepared and filed with the papers relating to such matter.
11-21-4: DECISION OF PLANNING COMMISSION ON AMENDMENTS:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 383/436
(A) Within forty (40) days after conclusion of a public hearing, the Commission shall by resolution make its findings, decision and recommendations in
the matter.
(B) In matters initiated by application, failure of the Commission to adopt such a resolution within such forty (40) day period shall be deemed to
constitute a denial of the application.
(C) In matters initiated by resolution of the Council, failure of the Commission to adopt such a resolution within the forty (40) day period shall be
deemed to constitute approval of the proposed amendment.
(D) In matters initiated by application, the Commission shall cause a copy of its resolution to be mailed to the applicant within ten (10) days from the
date of adoption thereof.
(E) In all matters, if the recommendation of the Commission is to approve the proposed action, it shall cause to be forwarded to the Council within ten
(10) days from the date of its action a copy of the resolution, a copy of the written summary of the testimony, and a copy of any recommended
amendment.
(F) In matters initiated by resolution of the Council, if the recommendation of the Commission is to disapprove the proposed action, its resolution and
other papers shall be forwarded to the Council as provided in the preceding Subsection (E).
11-21-5: APPEALS FROM DECISIONS OF PLANNING COMMISSION:
(A) In matters initiated by application, if the Commission denies the application, its denial may be appealed to the Council as follows:
1. The applicant, or any of the applicants, may within ten (10) days after the date of mailing, as shown by the postmark, or the papers mentioned in
Section 11-21-4 (D), or within ten (10) days after the expiration of the forty (40) day period mentioned in Section 11-21-4 (B), file in writing with
the Clerk an appeal from the decision of the Commission.
2. Any person interested, other than the applicant, may within ten (10) days after the date of adoption of the resolution containing the decision of
the Commission, or within ten (10) days after the expiration of the forty (40) day period mentioned in Section 11-21-4 (B), file in writing with the
Clerk an appeal from the decision of the Commission.
(B) If no appeal be filed within the time allowed in this Section, the denial by the Commission in a matter initiated by application shall be deemed final.
(C) On filing with the Clerk of an appeal, a public hearing shall be held thereon by the Council, which shall be set, noticed and decided substantially in
the same manner as provided in Section 11-21-6.
11-21-6: HEARINGS BY COUNCIL ON AMENDMENTS:
(A) Setting: Upon receipt of the resolution and other papers herein mentioned, the Council, or the Clerk, when so authorized by the Council, shall set a
time and place for a hearing on the matter, which shall be held within forty (40) days following such receipt; provided that in matters initiated by
resolution of the Council upon which the recommendation or report of the Commission has been unfavorable, the Council may determine to take
no further action.
(B) Notice: Notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be given by at least one (1) publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the City, at
least ten (10) days before the hearing.
(C) Decision: Within forty (40) days after the conclusion of the public hearing thereon, the Council shall by resolution make its findings and
determination whether or not to adopt the amendment. In matters initiated by application, failure of the Council to adopt such a resolution within the
forty (40) day period shall be deemed to constitute a denial.
(D) Effect: The action of the Council on such matters shall be final; provided, that no change shall be made in any amendment proposed by the
Commission until the proposed change has been referred to the Commission for a report and a copy of the report has been filed with the Council;
provided, that failure of the Commission to report within forty (40) days shall be deemed to be approval of the proposed change. (Ord. 533; 6-5-61)
Chapter 22
VARIANCES
11-22-1: AUTHORITY TO GRANT VARIANCES:
(A) The Board of Zoning Adjustment shall have authority to grant variances, pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter, and to specify terms and
conditions thereof. Any variance granted shall be subject to such conditions as will assure that the adjustment thereby authorized shall not
constitute a grant of special privilege inconsistent with the limitations upon other properties in the vicinity and zone in which subject property is
situated, and such other conditions as the Board deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this Title.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 384/436
11-22-2: GROUNDS FOR VARIANCES:
(A) The applicant for a variance shall show, and before a variance may be granted the Board shall find, as follows:
1. That because of special circumstances applicable to subject property, including size, shape, topography, location or surrounding, the strict
application of this Title deprives the subject property of privileges enjoyed by other properties in the vicinity and under identical zone
classification.
2. That the granting of the variance will not be materially detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to the property or improvements in the vicinity
or zone in which the property is located.
3. That the granting of such variance will not adversely affect the general plan or the purposes of this Title.
11-22-3: PROCEDURE; REVOCATION; MODIFICATION:
(A) The procedure for application for variances and the review and issuance thereof, shall be as provided in Sections 11-23-5 through 11-23-8,
inclusive.
(B) Variances may be revoked or modified in the manner and under the conditions set forth in Chapter 24. (Ord. 533; 6-5-61)
Chapter 23
BOARD OF ZONING ADJUSTMENT
11-23-1: BOARD CREATED; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
(A) There is hereby created a Board of Zoning Adjustment for the City hereafter referred to in this Title as the Board.
(B) The Board shall consist of three (3) members, who shall be appointed from the membership of the Commission by resolution of the Commission.
