(C) Prior to the adoption of the resolution appointing the first members to the Board, the Commission as a whole shall constitute the Board, with all the
powers and duties thereof.
(D) The term of office of the members of the Board shall be one (1) year; provided, that the first members appointed shall serve as follows: One (1) for
six (6) months, one (1) for one (1) year, and one (1) for eighteen (18) months.
(E) In event of a permanent vacancy of the Board, such vacancy shall be filled by the Commission for the unexpired term.
11-23-2: MATTERS CONSIDERED BY BOARD:
The Board shall hear and decide the following matters:
(A) Applications for variances.
(B) Applications for conditional use permits.
(C) Applications for extra heavy M-2 use permits.
(D) Appeals from administrative acts, where it is alleged by the appellant that there is error in any order, requirement, permit, decision or determination
made by an administrative official in the administration or enforcement of this Title, in which matters the Board shall have the authority and shall be
subject to the conditions set forth in Sections 65855, 65856, and 65857 of the Government Code of the State, commonly known as the
Conservation and Planning Law.
11-23-3: RULES OF BOARD:
(A) The general rules and procedures necessary or convenient for the conduct of the business of the Board, including rules relating to the time for and
manner of appeals from administrative acts as mentioned in Section 11-23-2 (A), shall be adopted by the Planning Commission.
(B) The Board may adopt from time to time such rules and procedures necessary or convenient for the conduct of its business as are not in conflict
with the general rules adopted for that purpose by the Planning Commission.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 385/436
(C) The majority in number of the total voting membership of the Board shall constitute a legal quorum. The concurrence of at least a majority of
members present shall be necessary for action on any matter.
11-23-4: WHERE BOARD MEMBERS UNABLE TO ATTEND:
(A) In event any member of the Board is unable to attend a meeting of the Board, the Chairman of the Commission may designate any other member
of the Commission to serve in his stead and with full voting rights at the meeting.
(B) All members of the Commission are hereby constituted as ex officio members of the Board for the foregoing purpose.
11-23-5: APPLICATION FOR AND INITIATION OF HEARINGS:
(A) Hearings on variances, conditional use permits and extra heavy M-2 use permits shall be initiated in any of the following manners:
1. By verified application of any interested person or persons.
2. By resolution of the Commission requesting the Board to hear the same.
(B) Upon filing with the Board of any such application or resolution, it shall hold a hearing thereon. The manner of setting, noticing, hearing and
determining such matter shall be substantially as provided in the following named provisions relating to amendments; provided, that all references
therein to the Commission shall be deemed to refer to the Board, and all references therein to the Council shall be deemed to refer to the
Commission and all references therein to amendments shall be deemed to refer to the matter to be considered by the Board.
The provisions are as follows:
Section 11-21-1 (B) and (C); Section 11-21-2 (C): Section 11-21-3 (A), (B), (F), and (G); Section 11-21-4 (A), (B), (C), (D), and (F).
11-23-6: TERM OF VARIANCE OR PERMIT; EXPIRATION:
(A) The Board may, in the granting of any variance, conditional use permit, or extra-heavy M-2 use permit, impose upon the permit a term of such
period of time as is found to be consistent with the purposes of the proposed use and necessary to safeguard the public safety, health and welfare.
(B) The Board may, in the granting of any variance, conditional use permit, or extra-heavy M-2 use permit, specify the time within which the proposed
use must be undertaken and actively and continuously pursued.
(C) Any permit or variance shall become null and void at the expiration of the term thereof, or if not undertaken and actively and continuously pursued
within the time specified in the permit or within one (1) year if no time be specified therein.
11-23-7: HEARING OF APPEALS FROM BOARD:
(A) All decisions of the Board shall be directly reviewable by the Council, which may affirm, reverse, or modify any such act or determination as it
deems just and equitable, after duly considering the purposes of the review, the grounds or factors to be considered, and making such findings, as
may be required by this Title in connection with the initial hearing of the particular matter; provided, that an appeal has been filed within the time
and in the manner provided in Subsection (B) of this Section.
(B) Appeals from decisions of the Board may be filed by the applicant or any person interested within the time and in the manner mentioned in Section
11-21-5 (A); provided, that all references therein to the Commission shall be deemed to refer to the Board.
(C) On filing with the Clerk of an appeal, a public hearing shall be held thereon by the Council, which shall be set, noticed and decided substantially in
the same manner provided in Section 11-21-6.
(D) The decision of the Council shall be final. The Clerk shall cause a copy of its resolution to be mailed to the appellant within ten (10) days from the
date of adoption thereof.
11-23-8: WHEN BOARD ACTION IS FINAL:
(A) Upon expiration of the time within which an appeal therefrom may be filed, and no appeal being filed within such time, the decision of the Board
shall be deemed final; but if an appeal is filed within such time, the decision of the Board shall be stayed pending determination of the appeal.
(B) Until the decision of the Board or Council has become final, as herein provided, no permit or license shall be issued for any use dependent upon
the granting of a variance, conditional use permit, or extra heavy M-2 use permit. (Ord. 533; 6-5-61)
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 386/436
Chapter 24
PERMITS; REVOCATION OR MODIFICATION
11-24-1: AUTHORITY TO REVOKE OR MODIFY:
The Commission may revoke or modify any extra heavy M-2 use permit, any conditional use permit, or any variance on any one (1) or more of the
grounds hereinafter named, after a hearing held and conducted as provided in Section 11-24-4.
11-24-2: GROUNDS FOR REVOCATION:
The grounds for such revocation shall be any of the following:
(A) That approval was obtained by means of fraud or misrepresentation of a material fact.
(B) That the permittee or holder of the variance has failed to undertake the use in question for an unreasonable period of time.
(C) That the use in question has ceased to exist, or has been suspended for one (1) year or more.
(D) That there is or has been a violation of or failure to observe the terms or conditions of the permit or variance, or the use has been conducted in
violation of the provisions of this Title, or any other provisions of this Code, or regulation.
(E) That the use to which the permit or variance applies has been conducted in a manner detrimental to the public safety, health and welfare, or so as
to be a nuisance.
11-24-3: GROUNDS FOR MODIFICATION:
The grounds for modification shall be any of the following:
(A) That the grounds which would otherwise justify a revocation of the permit or variance can be corrected or cured by a modification imposing new or
additional conditions.
(B) That improvement of methods or technological advances permit conduct of the use with adequate safeguards under the proposed modification.
(C) That one (1) or more of the original conditions of the permit or variance is unworkable, impractical, or otherwise fails to accomplish the original
aims.
11-24-4: INITIATION OF PROCEEDINGS AND HEARINGS:
Proceedings for such revocation or modification may be initiated, and shall be set for hearing, noticed, heard, and determined in substantially the
same manner as provided in the following named provisions relating to amendments; provided, that all references therein to amendments shall be
deemed to refer to the proposed revocation or modification.
The provisions are as follows:
Section 11-21-1; Section 11-21-2 (C); Section 11-21-3; Section 11-21-4 (A), (B), (C), (D), and (F).
11-24-5: HEARING OF APPEALS:
All decisions of the Commission in proceedings for such revocation or modification may be appealed and reviewed in substantially the same manner
as provided in the following named provisions relating to appeals from decisions of the Commission.
The provisions are as follows:
Section 11-21-5; Section 11-21-6 (A), (B), and (C).
The action of the Council on such matters shall be final. (Ord. 533; 6-5-61)
Chapter 25
ADMINISTRATION; ENFORCEMENT
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 387/436
11-25-1: APPLICATIONS:
(A) The Commission shall have authority to prescribe the form of all applications to be filed with the Commission or Board, and information to be
provided by applicants.
(B) The Commission may prepare and provide application forms for use of interested persons.
(C) The Commission and the Board shall have authority to refuse to receive for filing or consider matters where the form of application or the
information to be provided does not conform with the rules of the Commission and the Board, as the case may be; provided, however, that in
matters before the Commission or Board, respectively, minor defects or omissions may be waived or leave granted to correct the same, in the
discretion of the Commission or the Board, as the case may be. (Ord. 533, 6-5-61)
11-25-2: FILING FEES:
(A) A fee shall be paid to the City upon the filing of the applications for the following purposes or proceedings, in amounts to be established by
resolution of the City Council:
1. Amendment to the Zoning Code.
2. Variance.
3. Conditional use permit.
4. Revocation or modification of extra heavy, M-2, use permits or variance where the application is filed by a person other than a person owning or
leasing the property to which the permit or variance applies. (Ord. 932, 5-21-90)
11-25-3: USE PERMITS:
(A) The Council is empowered to designated, from time to time, an officer or employee of the City who shall have authority to issue use permits in
conformity with this Title.
(B) No use permit shall be issued for any use, building, occupancy or purpose which is in conflict with the provisions of this Title; and if such permit be
issued contrary to the provisions of this Title, it shall be null and void.
(C) A use permit shall be duly issued for such use or purpose prior to:
1. The initial occupancy or use of any new building or structure moved to a new site, or of new floor space or other addition to an existing building.
2. The change of type or class of use of an existing building.
3. A change of use of any unimproved premises, except to a use involving only the tilling of land or growing thereon of farm, garden or orchard
products.
11-25-4: INTERPRETATION:
(A) In interpreting and applying the provisions of this Title, the same shall be construed to be the minimum requirement for the promotion of the public
health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare.
(B) This Title shall not be so construed as to interfere with, abrogate or annul any easement, covenant or other agreement.
(C) Where this Title imposes more stringent restrictions on the use of land or buildings, or upon the height of buildings, or requires larger open spaces
around or different location of buildings than may be imposed or required by any other law, rule or regulation or by any easement, covenant or
agreement, then the provisions of this Title shall control.
11-25-5: VIOLATIONS DECLARED A NUISANCE; ABATEMENT PROCEEDINGS:
(A) Any building or structure erected, constructed, altered, enlarged, converted, moved or maintained contrary to the provisions of this Title, and any
use of any land, building or premises established, conducted, operated, or maintained contrary to the provisions of this Title, shall be and the same
is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance.
(B) Any act or condition in this Section declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance shall, upon order of the Council, by appropriate proceedings
begun by the Attorney, be abated, removed or enjoined in the manner prescribed by law; and such abatement shall be at the expense of the
persons creating, causing, committing, or maintaining it, and the expense shall be lien on the property on which the nuisance is maintained and a
personal obligation of the owner of the property, when so determined by resolution of the Council.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 388/436
(C) The remedies mentioned in this Section shall be cumulative and not exclusive.
11-25-6: REPEAL:
Ordinance No. 410, and all ordinances amending Ordinance No. 410 shall, concurrently and with the effective date of this Title, be repealed, provided:
(A) Such repeal shall not be deemed to effect the adoption by reference of the Zoning Map of the City as mentioned in Section 11-2-2 of this Title.
(B) All presently existing and valid permits, variances, and other proceedings issued or taken under Ordinance No. 410 and amendments thereto, shall
continue in full force and effect, and shall be subject to such proceedings, modification, or revocation as though issued under the provisions of this
Title.
(C) All nonconforming uses or nonconforming buildings lawfully existing or maintained under the provisions of Ordinance No. 410 immediately prior to
the repeal thereof shall be deemed to be nonconforming uses or nonconforming buildings lawfully existing at the time of the adoption of this Title,
subject however, to all provisions herein mentioned relating to the same. (Ord. 533; 6-5-61)
Chapter 26
SETBACK REGULATIONS
11-26-1: ADOPTION OF PLAN AND GENERAL PURPOSE:
(A) There is hereby adopted a precise plan limiting the location of buildings and other improvements with respect to existing or planned rights-of-way,
under authority of Title 7, Chapter 3, Article 10, of the Government Code of the State, for the purpose of implementing the General Plan of the City,
and to furnish a guide for the orderly physical growth and development of the City, and to promote and protect the public health, safety, and general
welfare. Such precise plan may be developed progressively by the addition thereto from time to time, in the manner prescribed by law, of detailed
plans for certain streets or highways.
(B) One of the purposes of this chapter is to so regulate the future location of buildings and other improvements as to furnish sufficient visibility for the
safe operation of vehicles upon and entering into streets and highways and sufficient visibility and places of safety for pedestrians, as respects
present and future rights-of-way.
(C) An additional purpose of this ordinance is to so regulate the future location of buildings and other improvements that the same shall continue to
conform to the Zoning Regulations of the City, when street or highway rights-of-way are extended to the precise plan lines, with relation to the
distance from the lot line determined by the new right-of-way line.
11-26-2: TITLE OF ORDINANCE:
This chapter may be referred to as the "Setback Regulations".
11-26-3: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, certain words and terms are herein defined as follows:
(A) "Building" shall mean any building, structure, or installation, whether located in, on, over or under the ground, and shall include (but shall not be
necessarily confined to) the following; walls; fences other than open fences; wells for water, oil, or other hydrocarbon products; tanks; off-street
parking spaces or facilities required by any provision of this Code; and swimming pools. The term "building" shall not include or apply to the
following: trees; shrubs; agricultural crops; open fences; public utilities installed under the provisions of law or franchise; walks, drive-ways;
irrigation pipes and related fixtures; off-street parking facilities or spaces not required by any provision of this Code: streets, curbs, and other
municipal facilities or installations.
(B) "City" shall mean this City.
(C) "Commission" shall mean the Planning Commission.
(D) "Council" shall mean the City Council.
(E) "Fence, open" shall mean a fence, fifty (50%) percent or more of the surface of which is open to the passage of light and vision on either any and
all horizontal planes, or any and all vertical planes, perpendicular to the vertical surface thereof.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 389/436
(F) "Improvement" shall mean the same as "building".
(G) "Precise plan line" shall mean a line shown on any map by which the precise plan of this Chapter is expressed, indicating the exterior boundary of
the proposed right-of-way of any street or highway.
(H) "Setback line" shall mean that line, measured from the precise plan line, beyond which no building or improvement would be permitted to be
erected or constructed under the provisions of the Zoning Regulations, if the lot line as defined by the Zoning Regulations were the same as the
precise plan line.
(I) "Zoning Regulations" shall mean the Zoning Regulations of this City as amended from time to time.
11-26-4: CONSTRUCTION:
The following rules of construction shall apply, unless inconsistent with the plain meaning of the context of this chapter.
(A) Tense: Words used in the present tense include the future.
(B) Number: Words used in the singular include the plural, and words used in the plural number include the singular.
(C) Shall and may: The word "shall" is mandatory; and the word "may" is permissive.
(D) Gender: The masculine shall include the feminine and the neuter.
(E) Headings: In event that there is any conflict or inconsistency between the headings of an Article, Section, or Paragraph of this Chapter, and the
context thereof, the said heading shall not be deemed to affect the scope, meaning, or intent of such context.
(F) Oath: The word "oath" shall include affirmation.
(G) Verification: The word "verification"' shall include declaration under penalty of perjury.
11-26-5: EFFECT OF REGULATIONS:
(A) It shall be unlawful to erect or locate any building or other improvement
1. within the space between a setback line and the adjacent street right-of-way line, or
2. within the space between adjacent setback lines.
(B) Where this chapter imposes more stringent restrictions on the erection or location of buildings or improvements than may be imposed or required
by any other provision of this Code, rule or regulation, or by any easement, covenant or agreement, then the provisions of this chapter shall control.
(C) Subdivisions: Street and highway design and location of right of way lines in any subdivision falling under the provisions of the Subdivision Map
Act of the State, or under the provisions of any provision of this Code controlling subdivisions and/or divisions of land other than subdivisions, as
amended from time to time, shall be based on the precise plan lines established by this chapter.
(D) Nonconforming buildings and improvements: If any building or other improvement existing at the time of the enactment of this chapter or
amendment hereto, the erection of which would be contrary to the provisions of this chapter, the same may continue with reasonable maintenance;
provided that such nonconforming building or improvement shall not be moved, enlarged or reconstructed except in a manner which shall cause it
to conform to this chapter, except to replace any portion destroyed by fire or other casualty which destroys not more than seventy-five percent
(75%) of its reasonable value.
11-26-6: SETBACK LINES, HOW ESTABLISHED:
(A) A precise plan establishing a setback line shall be adopted by means of a map or a written statement, or by a combination of the same, which
shows or describes such line; such statements shall be set forth in this chapter, and such maps shall be adopted by this chapter, and attached
hereto and made a part hereof by reference.
(B) Additional setback lines may be adopted by amendments to this Chapter, and changes in the lines established hereby or by such amendments
may be made by adding new maps, amendments of all or parts of maps, and written statements, or combinations of the same.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 390/436
(C) Any such map may be divided into parts and subparts, which may be separately shown or employed for purposes of amending the maps herein
mentioned.
(D) For sake of convenience and ready reference, in the adoption of this chapter and amendments thereof, said maps, the parts and subparts thereof
and such written statements, showing or describing such lines, may be designated as being a particular item or part of a section of this chapter.
(E) In amending or adding any designated subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, item or part of a section of this chapter, it shall not be necessary to
repeat the other subsections, paragraphs, subparagraphs, items or parts of such section. (Ord. 579; 12-2-63)

(B) GROUNDS FOR VARIANCES.
1. A variance shall be granted if the applicant shows and the Commission finds that any of the following are true:
(a) That because of special circumstances applicable to the subject property, including size, shape, topography or location, the strict application
of this Chapter would deprive the subject property of privileges enjoyed by a substantial number of other properties in the vicinity and fronting
on the same street or highway.
(b) That the nature of the property of the applicant is such that he will be substantially damaged unless the proposed building or improvement is
authorized.
(c) That the applicant's property will not earn a fair return on the applicant's investment unless the proposed building or improvement is
authorized.
(d) That, balancing the interests of the public in effecting the purposes of this Chapter against the interest of the applicant in using his property
with the proposed building or improvement thereon, the granting of the variances is required by consideration of justice and equity.
2. A variance shall not be granted if the Commission finds that any of the following are true:
(a) That the applicant will not be substantially damaged by locating the proposed building or other improvement at a point on his property behind
the setback line.
(b) That, balancing the interest of the public in effecting the purposes of this chapter against the interest of the applicant in using his property with
the proposed building or improvement thereon, the resulting disadvantage to the public would be unreasonably disproportionate to the
advantages to the applicant to be derived from so using his property.
11-26-8: PROCEDURES ON VARIANCES:
(A) Initiation: Variances shall be initiated by the verified application of any owner of property claiming to be entitled to a variance therefor, or of his
agent, which shall be filed with the Commission.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 391/436
(B) Hearing and Notice: The Commission shall hold at least one public hearing on the matter of such application for variance. Notice of the time and
place of such hearing shall be given by at least one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the City at least ten (10) days before the
hearing and by such other means as the Commission may deem necessary.
(C) Continuance: Any such hearing may be continued by the vote of the majority of the members present at such hearing, who may fix a time and
place to which such hearing shall be so continued, even in the absence of a quorum, in which case the presiding officer at such hearing shall
publicly announce prior to the conclusion of the hearing the time and place to which the hearing is to be continued, and no further notice shall be
required.
(D) Quorum and Voting: The number of members necessary for a quorum, and the number of votes necessary for the adoption of any resolution
granting or denying a variance, shall be a majority of the total voting membership of the Commission. All other matters shall be determined by the
majority vote of the members present.
(E) Report of Investigation: The Commission may consider at such hearing any report of any investigation by a committee of one or more members of
the Commission, or its staff, authorized by the Commission in its discretion.
(F) Reference to Council: Within thirty (30) days after adoption of a resolution granting a variance, the Commission shall file a copy thereof with the
Council.
(G) Consideration by Council: Within thirty (30) days after receipt of a copy of such resolution, the Council shall consider the same at a public meeting.
No notice of the consideration of such matter shall be required.
(H) Grounds: The approval or disapproval by the Council of the granting of said variance, or of any conditions attached thereto, shall be upon the
grounds specified in Section 11-26-7(B). The Council may impose new or different conditions to the granting of the variance. The action of the
Council shall be final.
(I) If the Council fails to adopt a resolution approving or disapproving the granting of said variance, or imposing a new or different condition to the
granting thereof, within thirty (30) days from the date of receipt of the copy of the resolution of the Commission by the Clerk, then such variance
shall be deemed to be granted with the conditions as provided to the resolution of the Commission.
11-26-9: APPEALS:
(A) Any applicant not satisfied with the action of the Commission, or whose application has been denied, or whose application has not been finally
acted upon by the Commission within a period of sixty (60) days after the filing of the application, may file an appeal in writing with the Council
within ten (10) days after the final action of the Commission or within sixty (60) days after the filing of said application in the case of no final action,
and the Council shall hold a public hearing with respect thereto.
(B) Such public hearing shall be conducted within thirty (30) days after the filing of such written appeal, and the final decision of the Council shall be
made within thirty (30) days after the public hearing. Failure of the Council to take final action within sixty (60) days from the date of the filing of the
written appeal shall be deemed to be a denial of the appeal.
(C) Notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be given by at least one (1) publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the City at least
ten (10) days before the hearing.
(D) On such appeal, the Council may grant the variance, or deny the granting of same, or attach conditions thereto, upon the grounds specified in
Section 11-26-7(B).
11-26-10: AMENDMENTS, PROCEDURE:
(A) The procedure for adoption of amendments to this chapter shall be as set forth in Title 7, Chapter 3, Article 11, of the Government Code of the
State of California (Section 65650 et. seq.) and otherwise under the applicable provisions of this chapter, if any, not in conflict therewith.
11-26-11: VIOLATIONS DECLARED A NUISANCE:
(A) Any building or other improvement erected or located or maintained contrary to the provisions of this chapter shall be and the same is hereby
declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance.
(B) Any act or condition in this section declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance shall, upon order of the Council, by appropriate proceedings
begun by the Attorney, be abated, removed, or enjoined in the manner prescribed by law; and such abatement shall be at the expense of the
persons creating, causing, committing, or maintaining it, and such expense shall be a lien on the property on which the nuisance is maintained and
a personal obligation of the owner of such property, when so determined by resolution of the Council.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 392/436
(C) The remedies mentioned in this section shall be cumulative and not exclusive. (Ord. 579; 12-2-63)
Chapter 27
INTERIM SCHOOL FACILITIES
11-27-1: TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known and cited as the "Interim School Facilities Ordinance".
11-27-2: AUTHORITY:
This Chapter is adopted pursuant to the provisions of chapter 4.7 (commencing with section 65970) of division 1 of title 7 of the Government Code.
11-27-3: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this Chapter is to provide a method of financing interim school facilities necessitated by conditions of overcrowding caused by new
residential developments.
11-27-4: REGULATIONS:
The City Council may, from time to time by resolution, issue regulations to provide for the administration and implementation of this Chapter.
11-27-5: GENERAL PLAN:
The City General Plan provides for the location of public schools. Land required to be dedicated hereunder shall be consistent with the General Plan.
11-27-6: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter:
APPROVE A RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT: For any residential development to:
(A) Issue a building permit;
(B) Approve a tentative, final or parcel map for subdivision of land; or
(C) Approve, grant or issue a variance, special permit, site plan review or planned development permit.
CONDITIONS OF OVERCROWDING: The total enrollment of a school attendance area, including enrollment from proposed development,
exceeds the capacity of such school attendance area as determined by the governing body of the district.
DECISION-MAKING BODY: The City Council, Planning Commission and such other board, commission, office or official as may be authorized or
empowered to approve a residential development.
DWELLING UNIT: A building or portion thereof, or a mobile home, designed for residential occupation by one person or a group of two (2) or more
persons living together as a domestic unit. Dwelling unit shall not mean room additions to existing residential structures.
REASONABLE METHODS OF MITIGATING CONDITIONS OF OVERCROWDING: Shall include, but are not limited to:
(A) Agreements between a developer and the affected school district whereby fees are paid directly by a developer to the school district, or temporary
use buildings will be leased to or for the benefit of the school district, or temporary use buildings owned by the developer or school district will be
used by the district;
(B) The use of relocatable structures, student transportation, classroom double sessions, year-round school programs, school boundary realignments
and elimination of low priority school facility uses;
(C) The use of available tax and bond, and other revenue procedures, to the extent authorized by law.
RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT: (A) The construction or one or more home dwelling units, mobile or otherwise;
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 393/436
(B) The construction of a mobile home park;
(C) The subdivision of real property for the purpose of such construction or for the purpose of converting existing multiple family structures to
condominium stock cooperative ownership; or
(D) The conversion to a residential use of an existing structure or part thereof pursuant to a variance, special use permit, planned development permit
or other discretionary planning permit.
11-27-7: FINDINGS BY SCHOOL DISTRICT:
Pursuant to Government Code sections 65970 et seq., the governing board of a school district which has not received an apportionment pursuant to
the Leroy F. Green State School Building Lease - Purchase Law of 1976 (commencing with section 17700 of the California Education Code), with
respect to any of its attendance areas located in whole or in part within the incorporated territory of the City, may make and file with the City Council a
written notice of findings supported by clear and convincing evidence that:
(A) Conditions of overcrowding exist in the school or schools of such attendance area which will impair the normal functioning of educational
programs, including the reason for such conditions existing; and
(B) All reasonable methods for mitigating conditions of overcrowding have been evaluated and considered by the governing board and no feasible
method of reducing such conditions exists.
11-27-8: CONTENT OF FINDINGS:
The notice of findings filed pursuant to Section 11-27-7 shall contain the following:
(A) A precise description of the geographic boundaries of the attendance areas to which the findings relate;
(B) A list of the mitigation measures evaluated by the governing board of the school district and a statement of the reasons why such measures were
found to be infeasible;
(C) A summary of the evidence upon which such findings are based; and
(D) Such other information as may be required by regulations adopted by the City Council pursuant to this Chapter.
11-27-9: ACTION BY CITY COUNCIL:
After receipt of the notice findings complying with the requirements of this Chapter, and following a noticed public hearing thereon, the City Council
shall, by resolution, either concur in or reject such findings. The Council shall concur in the findings by resolution if the documentation and evidence
clearly and convincingly demonstrate to the Council the existence of conditions of overcrowding and the lack of feasible methods of mitigating
conditions of overcrowding within an attendance area of the district. Within an attendance area as to which the Council has concurred in a finding of
overcrowding and the lack of feasible mitigating measures, the approval of a residential development by any decision-making body shall be
conditioned upon the dedication of land or the payment of fees, or both, in the discretion of the decision-making body. At any time after it has
concurred in or rejected such findings, the Council may reconsider the matter, in a noticed public hearing.
11-27-10: SCHOOL DISTRICT SCHEDULE:
The school district shall also file with the City Council a schedule specifying how and when the school district will use fees or land received by it
pursuant to this Chapter to solve the conditions of overcrowding. The schedule shall include the school sites to be used, and the classroom facilities to
be made available, and the time when such facilities will be available. If the school district cannot meet the schedule, it shall file modifications with the
City Council together with a statement of the reasons for the modifications.
11-27-11: FINDINGS BY CITY COUNCIL:
After receipt of the schedule, the City Council shall, by resolution, determine whether the facilities and land use specified in such schedule are
consistent with the General Plan.
11-27-12: FINDINGS BY DECISION-MAKING BODY:
Within any attendance area where it has been determined pursuant to this Chapter that conditions of overcrowding exist, and where the City Council
has concurred in such findings, no decision-making body shall approve a residential development unless such decision-making body first determines
one of the following:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 394/436
(A) That the school district has entered into an agreement with the applicant or some other person which provides a feasible means for mitigating any
aggravation of such conditions of overcrowding which would be caused by the residential development.
(B) That the applicant has paid the school fees as required by this Section;
(C) That there are specific, overriding fiscal, economic, social or environmental factors which would benefit the City which justify approval of the
residential development without requiring the payment of fees otherwise required pursuant to this Chapter.
11-27-13: FACILITIES FEES AND DEDICATIONS:
The amount of the facilities fees per dwelling unit shall be set by resolution of the City Council after consultation with the affected school districts, and
shall bear a reasonable relationship and will be limited to the needs of the community for interim elementary, junior high and high school facilities and
shall be reasonably related and limited to the need for schools caused by residential development. However, fees shall not exceed the amount
necessary to pay five (5) annual lease payments for interim facilities prorated per student. The fee shall be paid at the time of the issuance of a
building permit, or when none is required, before occupancy of an existing structure.
11-27-14: DETERMINATION OF STUDENT POPULATION DENSITY AND DWELLING UNITS:
(A) Student population and density for the purpose of this Chapter shall be determined by resolution of the City Council based upon the number of
students reasonably expected to be housed in each dwelling unit in the development.
(B) The number of dwelling units shall be determined by reference to the building permit or map permitting conversion of existing structures to
residential use.
11-27-15: DEDICATION OR PROVISION OF FACILITIES IN LIEU OF FEES:
(A) A developer may dedicate land in lieu of paying the fees required by this Section. However, the payment of fees may be required only in
subdivisions containing fifty (50) or fewer parcels.
(B) The developer may, at his option and expense in lieu of fees, provide interim facilities meeting the standards and at a location established by the
affected school district. The developer shall remove such facilities at the conclusion of the fifth school year at his expense unless the developer and
the school district agree that such facilities may remain.
11-27-16: APPLICATION OF FEES:
(A) The fees collected pursuant to this Chapter shall be retained by the school district to be expended as required by this Section.
(B) The fees, land or facilities, or combination thereof, shall be used by the school district as and for interim facilities in accordance with the
requirements of chapter 4.7, division 1, title 7 of the Government Code, and as defined in section 65980 thereof.
11-27-17: SCHOOL DISTRICT REPORT, FREQUENCY THEREOF, CONTENTS:
The school district shall maintain a separate account for any fees received and shall file a report with the City Council on the balance in the account at
the end of the previous fiscal year and the facilities leased, purchased or constructed during the previous fiscal year. In addition, the report shall
specify which attendance areas will continue to be overcrowded when the fall term begins, and where conditions of overcrowding will no longer exist.
Such report shall be filed by October 15 of each year and shall be filed more frequently at the request of the City Council. If overcrowding no longer
exists, the City shall cease levying fees pursuant to this Chapter for residential development in that attendance area.
11-27-18: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection or portion of this Chapter is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by the decision of any court of competent
jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portion of this Chapter. The City Council hereby declares that it would have
adopted this Chapter and any section, subsection or portion thereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or more section, subsections or portions be
declared invalid or unconstitutional. (Ord. 874, 1-21-85)
Chapter 28
SIGN REGULATIONS
11-28-1: PURPOSE:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 395/436
The purpose of this chapter is to provide minimum standards to safeguard the life, health, property, and public welfare in keeping with the character of
the city by establishing and maintaining standards for the size, height, structural design, quality of materials, construction, location, illumination, and
maintenance of all exterior signs and sign structures including signs attached to or affixed upon the interior of windows, and to accomplish the
following results:
(A) To protect and enhance the character of residential neighborhoods and property values by prohibiting obtrusive and incompatible signs; and
(B) To promote and maintain healthy commercial centers and property values by providing for the effective communication of the nature of goods and
services and the avoidance of wasteful and unsightly competition in signs; and
(C) To provide a reasonable and comprehensive system of controls for signs; and
(D) To encourage a desirable urban character, which has a minimum of overhead clutter; and
(E) To encourage signs which are well designed and pleasing in appearance and to provide incentive and latitude for variety, good design relationship,
spacing, and location; and
(F) To attract and direct persons to various activities and enterprises in order to provide for maximum public convenience; and
(G) To enhance the economic value of the community through the regulation of the size, location, design, and illumination of signs. (Ord. 95-9, 8-7-
1995)
11-28-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS AND INSPECTIONS:
(A) Administration: It shall be the duty of the community development department to enforce the provisions of this chapter.
(B) Inspections: Every sign erected in the city shall be subject to inspection to assure compliance with the provisions of this chapter and all other laws
and ordinances of the city.
(C) Permits Required: Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to erect, alter, relocate, change, or otherwise
modify a sign within the city without first obtaining a sign review and approval from the community development department.
(D) Legal Interest In Property: In order to file an application for any action under this chapter, the applicant shall have a certain legal interest in the real
property which is the subject of the application. Legal interest shall be one of the following:
1. Owner;
2. Lessee, limited to the portion being leased and excluding common access drives and common parking areas; or
3. A verified agent of one of those listed above (such as a licensed sign contractor).
(E) Applications; Procedure: Applications for permits required by the provisions of this chapter shall be made to the city community development
department on forms provided by the city, shall be accompanied by a permit fee as set by the city council by resolution and shall contain the
following information:
1. The name, address and telephone number of the owner of the property;
2. The name, address and telephone number of the applicant (sign owner);
3. The name, address and telephone number of the sign contractor;
4. The location of the building, structure or lot where the sign will be placed;
5. Three (3) copies of a plan showing the following:
(a) The location and size of all existing or proposed buildings or structures on the parcel where the sign will be located.
(b) The location of all off-street parking facilities, including major points of entry and exit.
(c) Fully dimensioned drawings showing the proposed design, size, colors, materials, location of the sign or sign structures and elevations if the
sign is to be placed on a building.
(d) The location and size of all existing freestanding signs on the parcel. The location and size of all wall signs, if the sign is to be placed on a
wall. Tenants in office or shopping centers only must show wall signs which pertain to their place of business.
6. Such other information as the Community Development Department shall require to show full compliance with the provisions of this Chapter and
all other laws and ordinances of the City.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 396/436
(F) Approval Of Sign Reviews: The Community Development Department shall approve, conditionally approve or deny a sign review application based
on the following criteria:
1. The application has been properly made; and
2. The sign complies with the laws of the City; and
3. The permit fee has been paid; and
4. The sign's location and copy does not create a potential visibility or safety hazard; and
5. The sign does not require a conditional use permit as required by this Title.
(G) Referral To Planning Commission: The Community Development Director, at his discretion, may refer any application to the Planning Commission,
which may approve, conditionally approve, or deny the sign application in accordance with the criteria listed above.
(H) Action On Application: If a sign application is denied, the Community Development Department shall provide written notice of the denial to the
applicant after the decision is rendered. The applicant may appeal any decision of the Community Development Director to the Planning
Commission pursuant to the provisions of the appeals portion of this Chapter (subsection 11-28-2(I)).
If a sign is approved, the applicant shall obtain any required permits from the Building Division prior to installing, altering or relocating any sign.
(I) Appeals:
1. The applicant or any aggrieved person may appeal a decision, on an item pertaining to this Chapter, made by the Community Development
Director to the Planning Commission. Such an appeal shall be filed in writing, in the format prescribed by the Community Development Director,
not later than ten (10) calendar days after a decision has been rendered. The appeal shall be accompanied by the fee required for an "Appeal of
a Staff Decision, Minor" and any pertinent data the appellant wishes to submit. The appeal shall be scheduled for the next regular Planning
Commission meeting, provided the meeting is at least fourteen (14) calendar days from the date of the appeal. If the next meeting is sooner than
fourteen (14) days, the appeal shall be scheduled for the meeting following the next scheduled meeting.
2. The applicant or any aggrieved person may appeal a decision, on an item pertaining to this Chapter, made by the Planning Commission to the
City Council. Such an appeal shall be filed in writing, in the format prescribed by the Community Development Director, not later than ten (10)
calendar days after a decision has been rendered by the Planning Commission. The appeal shall be accompanied by the fee required for an
"Appeal of a Planning Commission Decision" and any pertinent data the appellant wishes to submit. The appeal shall be scheduled for the next
regular City Council meeting provided the meeting is at least fourteen (14) calendar days from the date of appeal. If the next meeting is sooner
than fourteen (14) days, the appeal shall be scheduled for the meeting following the next scheduled meeting. (Ord. 95-9, 8-7-95)
11-28-3: EXEMPT SIGNS:
(A) The following signs, if not illuminated and unless specifically provided for, shall be exempt from filing a sign application, however, they shall comply
with all other applicable requirements of this Chapter:
1. Notices or signs required to be posted by law.
2. Signs of a duly constituted governmental body required for official business.
3. Official traffic, fire and police related signs, temporary traffic control signs used during construction, utility identification signs, and other official
signs as required by the City State department or other official agency.
4. Temporary signs for the purpose of announcing civic events sponsored by the City and/or the Chamber of Commerce.
5. One each national, State and corporate flag, provided that the flags are displayed properly and comply with the United States Flag Code.
6. Holiday decorations, provided that they are appropriate to the holiday they represent and such decorations are not displayed in excess of an
aggregate of ninety (90) days.
7. Residential signs identifying the address or occupant of a single-family home, provided such signs do not exceed four (4) square feet in
aggregate. Residential address signs may be illuminated. Curb addresses shall not be counted against the allowable sign area. All address signs
shall be in accordance with applicable Fire Department regulations.
8. Signs inside buildings.
9. Emergency information signs not exceeding two (2) square feet which are limited to the name of the business, contact person and emergency
phone numbers.
10. Permanent window signs indicating hours of operation, credit card signs and similar ancillary business signs, provided the aggregate of such
signs does not exceed four (4) square feet. Additionally "open", "closed" and "help wanted" signs may be placed provided they do not exceed
three (3) square feet each. Signs indicating "open" and "closed" may be illuminated.
11. For sale, for rent, open house, garage sale, and similar signs, provided that no more than two (2) such signs are on the premises for which they
are advertising, they do not exceed eight (8) square feet per sign face and they are not placed in the public right of way.
12. Weekend off-site subdivision directional and off-site open house signs subject to the following regulations:
(a) Such signs shall not exceed ten (10) signs per subdivision or shall not exceed two (2) signs per open house.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 397/436
(b) Such signs shall not exceed four (4) square feet.
(c) Such signs shall not be placed in any public right of way or on any public utility fixture. No sign shall be placed without the property owner's
permission.
(d) Signs shall be posted no earlier than five o'clock (5:00) P.M. of Friday afternoon and shall be removed not later than nine o'clock (9:00) A.M.
on Monday morning. If a legal holiday extends the weekend, signs may be posted during that holiday.
(e) Off-site subdivision and open house signs shall be subject to abatement as per subsection 11-28-4(G)2.
13. Off-site subdivision directional signs which are part of a City and Chamber of Commerce sponsored program approved by the City Council.
14. Temporary noncommercial signs including, but not limited to, religious, charitable, civic, homeowner association, educational, cultural, or
political signs, provided that such signs comply with the following regulations:
(a) Such signs shall not exceed thirty two (32) square feet per sign face.
(b) No such sign shall be posted for a period of more than thirty (30) days before an event or sixty (60) days before an election and all such signs
shall be removed within seven (7) days of the completion of the event or election.
(c) Such signs shall not be stuck, glued, painted, pasted, posted, nailed, stapled or otherwise attached to any public property, in the public right
of way, publicly owned sign, utility pole, fire hydrant or similar fixture. It shall be unlawful to erect a sign or direct the erection of a sign without
the permission of the property owner.
(d) It shall be presumed that the organization or candidate which benefits from a sign is the party who erected the sign.
(e) Upon determination of a violation of the provisions of this subsection regulating temporary noncommercial signs, the Community
Development Department shall contact the property owner of the parcel in question and request that the illegal sign be voluntarily abated. If
the signs are not removed from private property within twenty four (24) hours, the Community Development Director may direct the removal of
such signs. Signs on public property may be removed immediately and without notice. The Community Development Department shall send
notification in writing to the owner of such sign, if the owner can be determined, stating the location where the sign is being held and that the
sign will be destroyed if not claimed by the owner within ten (10) days of such notice. If the sign is not claimed within the allotted time period,
the Director shall have the sign destroyed or disposed of. The Community Development Director shall not release any confiscated signs
without payment by the owner to reimburse the City for any costs incurred for the abatement and storage of the sign. If the sign is not claimed
the owner shall be responsible for the cost of abatement, storage and disposal of the sign and the City shall bill the owner to recover the costs
incurred by the City.
(f) No portion of this subsection shall prohibit the owner, or his authorized representative, of a piece of property from removing a sign from his
property. Further nothing in this subsection shall prohibit the Director from directing the immediate abatement of dangerous and unsafe signs.
(Ord. 95-9, 8-7-95)
11-28-4: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
(A) Purpose: The following general provisions are applicable to all signs and billboards regulated by this Chapter.
(B) Entitlements Strictly Construed: Because the regulations in this Chapter are established to protect the public health, safety and general welfare,
any sign entitlement authorized hereunder shall be strictly construed to further the purposes of this Chapter.
(C) Illumination Of Signs: Unless otherwise prohibited by this Chapter, signs requiring a permit may be illuminated subject to approval by the
Community Development Department.
(D) Obstruction Of Public Passage: No sign shall be erected so as to obstruct any door, fire escape or other emergency exit of any building. No sign
shall be erected in any public right of way.
(E) Construction: All signs, parts and supporting structures shall be constructed in compliance with all applicable Federal, State and City laws and
regulations. Any person engaged in the construction of signs shall have appropriate and valid licenses.
(F) Maintenance Of Signs: The following maintenance standards shall apply to all signs:
1. All signs, parts and supporting structures shall be continuously maintained in a safe, structurally sound, neatly painted, and well repaired
condition.
2. Illuminated signs shall be capable of being fully illuminated and legible. The faces of such a sign shall be intact without holes or other facial
damage.
(G) Enforcement: The Community Development Department is responsible for the enforcement of this Chapter.
1. Permanent Signs: Upon determination of a violation of the provisions of this Chapter, the Community Development Department shall contact the
property owner of the parcel in question and request that the illegal sign be voluntarily abated. The Community Development Department shall
provide the owner with at least three (3) notices not closer than two (2) weeks apart. If after ninety (90) days no action is taken by the owner, the
Community Development Director may direct the removal of such signs after a resolution is passed by the City Council declaring the sign a
public nuisance. A minimum of ten (10) days notice shall be given to all persons owning property described in the resolution prior to its adoption
in accordance with chapter 2.6 of the California Business and Professions Code. After a sign's removal the Community Development
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 398/436
Department shall send notification in writing to the owner of the property stating the location where the sign is being held and that the sign will be
destroyed if not claimed by the owner within ten (10) days of such notice. If the sign is not claimed within the allotted time period, the Director
shall have the sign destroyed or disposed of. The Community Development Department shall not release any confiscated signs without a
payment by the owner to reimburse the City for any cost incurred for the abatement and storage of the sign. If the sign is not claimed the owner
shall be responsible for the cost of abatement, storage and disposal of the sign and the City shall bill the owner to recover the costs incurred by
the City.
2. Temporary Signs: Upon determination of a violation of the provisions of this Chapter regulating temporary signs, the Community Development
Department shall contact the property owner of the parcel in question and request the illegal sign be voluntarily abated. If the signs are not
removed from private property within twenty four (24) hours, the Community Development Director shall direct the removal of such signs. Signs
on public property may be removed immediately and without notice. The Community Development Department shall send notification in writing
to the owner of such sign, if the owner can be determined, stating the location where the sign is being held and that the sign will be destroyed if
not claimed by the owner within ten (10) days of such notice. If the sign is not claimed within the allotted time period, the Director shall have the
sign destroyed or disposed of. The Community Development Department shall not release any confiscated signs without payment by the owner
to reimburse the City for any costs incurred for the abatement and storage of the sign. If the sign is not claimed the owner shall be responsible
for the cost of abatement, storage and disposal of the sign and the City shall bill the owner to recover the costs incurred by the City.
(H) Existing Nonconforming Signs: All nonconforming signs which have been legally erected prior to the adoption of this Chapter shall be legal
nonconforming signs. It shall be legal for such signs to have their copy changed, provided they submit a sign application to the Community
Development Director for review as outlined below in subsection (I). Any physical changes, modifications or upgrades of a legal nonconforming
sign structure, not related to normal maintenance activities, shall be required to comply with all provisions of this Chapter.
All legal nonconforming signs shall be brought into compliance with this Chapter twenty (20) years after the adoption of this Chapter by the City
Council pursuant to section 5495 of the Business and Professions Code. Any sign which is not brought into compliance may at that time be subject
to abatement as a public nuisance.
(I) Change Of Copy: A change of copy shall consist of only changing the copy for a sign cabinet, wall sign or similar structure. Except for maintenance
of existing copy, painted signs, on walls or windows, shall not be eligible for a change of copy. All change of copy requests shall be submitted to the
Community Development Department for the tracking of signage within the City. Provided there are no physical changes to the sign structure and
no other portion of this Chapter is violated, the request shall be approved by the Community Development Department. There shall be no fees for a
change of copy request. The applicant shall file the request on an application form provided by Community Development Department and shall
include a dimensioned illustration of the proposed new sign copy.
(J) Right To Remove: No portion of this Chapter shall prohibit the owner, or his authorized representative, of a piece of property from removing a sign
from his property. Further, nothing in this subsection shall prohibit the Director from directing the immediate abatement of dangerous and unsafe
signs. (Ord. 95-9, 8-7-95)
11-28-5: PROHIBITED SIGNS:
(A) In addition to any sign not specifically permitted in accordance with this Chapter, the following signs shall be prohibited:
1. Animated signs.
2. Flashing signs, except for time and temperature signs and electronic reader boards.
3. Revolving signs, except barber poles.
4. Movable signs mounted on trailers, trucks or similar conveyance.
5. Pennants, banners and flags except as specifically permitted by this Chapter.
6. Off-site signs, except as specifically permitted by this Chapter.
7. Signs that display a message, graphic presentation, or other image that is obscene as defined by section 311 of the California Penal Code.
8. Roof Signs: All signs mounted on or above the roof line of a building, except that, the placement of signs on a mansard roof are permitted
provided that such signs are placed in the lower two-thirds (2/3) of the mansard and no portion of the sign extends into the top one-third (1/3) of
the mansard roof. All mansard roof signs shall be integrated into the mansard structure.
9. Projecting Signs: No projecting signs are permitted, except barber poles which may project twenty four inches (24").
10. Signs imitative of official street and traffic control signs, except when used for on-site traffic direction. Such signs would include those which
contain or imitate an official traffic sign or signal, or containing the words stop, go, slow, caution, danger, warning, or similar words which in
context of the sign could be misconstrued to be a traffic or safety warning sign.
11. Signs which are cut, burned, limed, painted or otherwise marked on a field, tree, rock or other natural feature. (Ord. 95-9, 8-7-95)
11-28-6: PERMITTED SIGNS:
(A) Maximum Entitlements: The size and quantity regulations set forth in this Section shall be the maximum permitted sign entitlements under this
Chapter. The use of the subject property determines the signage allowed in all zone districts.
(B) Determination Of Sign Area:
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 399/436
1. Multiple signs for the same business or use shall be added together when determining existing and allowable sign area.
2. Nonintegrated signs, such as individual letters when not in a frame area, shall have their area determined by the number of square feet of the
smallest rectangle in which the entire copy of the proposed sign can be enclosed. If a particular letter or symbol is fifty percent (50%) or more in
height than the other letters or symbols, then the larger letter or symbol may be enclosed in a separate rectangle but still added into the total sign
area.
3. Three (3) dimensional objects, such as globes and cylinders, shall have their area determined by calculating the surface area of the object which
will be used for signage. Cubes and objects with signage on flat surfaces shall use the area of the flat surfaces. If the object is less than two feet
(2') in width or diameter, then the area shall be calculated as if the object were flat.
4. The base of all monument sign shall not be included in the allowable sign area but shall be included for maximum height.
(C) Sign Variance: The Community Development Director may grant a sign variance for a sign, provided that strict and literal interpretation and
enforcement of this Chapter would create an unnecessary hardship to the applicant. An unnecessary hardship may result from the size, shape, or
dimensions of a site, or the existing locations of structures on the site, or the physical conditions on the site or immediately adjacent to the site. In
no case shall the variance be granted for greater than ten percent (10%) of any one aspect of the sign. The applicant shall file an application as
provided by the Community Development Department, fees and an exact statement as to what hardship would be created. The decision of the
Director may be appealed to the Planning Commission as per the appeals section of this Chapter (subsection 11-28-2(I)).
(D) Setbacks: All freestanding signs shall be setback a minimum of five feet (5') from any property line as measured from the nearest portion of the
sign and its supports. (Ord. 95-9, 8-7-95)
11-28-6-1: RESIDENTIAL SIGNS:
(A) Single-Family Homes And Subdivision:
1. Model Home Signs: Each model home may have one model home sign not to exceed six (6) square feet and not to exceed five feet (5') in
height. In addition, each model home may have one flag per twenty feet (20') of street frontage. Such flags shall not exceed fifteen (15) square
feet in area and shall be mounted no more than eighteen feet (18') in height to the top of the flag. Model home signs may be illuminated,
however, the flags shall not be illuminated.
2. Subdivision Sales Sign: Each single-family home tract shall be permitted one sales sign per major arterial or one sales sign on the primary
frontage if not adjacent to a major arterial. Subdivision sales signs shall not exceed sixty four (64) square feet in area and shall not exceed a
height of eight feet (8'). Subdivision sales sign may be illuminated, the remainder shall be nonilluminated.
3. Subdivision Entry Signs: Each single-family subdivision is permitted one permanent entry sign for each side of the street at each entrance
adjacent to a major arterial or its primary frontage if not adjacent to a major arterial. Subdivision entry signs shall not exceed forty (40) square
feet or a height of six feet (6'). All subdivision entry signs shall be constructed of masonry or other durable materials and integrated into walls or
fences. Landscaping and other features are encouraged to accentuate the entrance.
(B) Multiple-Family Dwellings:
1. Identification Signs: Each multi-family complex is permitted one permanent identification sign per two hundred fifty feet (250') of street frontage
or fraction thereof. Identification signs shall not exceed forty (40) square feet or a height of six feet (6'). All identification shall be constructed of
masonry or other durable materials and integrated into walls or fences. Landscaping and other features are encouraged to accentuate the sign.
(C) Mobile Home Parks:
1. Identification Signs: Each mobile home park is permitted one permanent identification sign per two hundred fifty feet (250') of street frontage or
fraction thereof. Identification signs shall not exceed forty (40) square feet or a height of six feet (6'). All identification shall be constructed of
masonry or other durable materials and integrated into walls or fences. Landscaping and other features are encouraged to accentuate the sign.
(Ord. 95-9, 8-7-95)
11-28-6-2: COMMERCIAL SIGNS:
(A) Single Tenant Retail Or Office Buildings Not Part Of A Shopping Or Office Center, Including Hospitals, Medical Clinics, Hotels And Motels:
1. Freestanding Signs: Single tenant retail or office buildings not part of a shopping or office center shall be permitted the following freestanding
signs based on the developed portion of the site:
(a) Sites Less Than Five Acres: One freestanding sign per two hundred fifty feet (250') of street frontage or fraction thereof. The sign face area
shall not exceed sixty (60) square feet and the overall sign height shall not exceed twenty feet (20'). Sign area shall not be exchanged
between signs.
(b) Sites Five Acres Or Greater: One freestanding sign per two hundred fifty feet (250') of street frontage or fraction thereof. The sign face area
shall not exceed one hundred (100) square feet and the overall sign height shall not exceed twenty feet (20'). Sign area shall not be
exchanged between signs.
2. Wall Signs: Each single tenant retail or office building not part of a shopping or office center shall be permitted two (2) square feet of sign area
per linear foot of building frontage adjacent to a street, parking area or access drive. Sign area shall not be exchanged between walls.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 400/436
(B) Shopping And Office Centers:
1. Sign Program: All multi-tenant shopping or office centers shall submit a sign program to the Community Development Department for review and
approval.
2. Freestanding Signs: Each shopping or office center is permitted one freestanding sign per two hundred fifty feet (250') of street frontage or
fraction thereof. The sign face area shall not exceed one hundred (100) square feet and the overall sign height shall not exceed twenty feet (20').
Sign area shall not be exchanged between signs.
(a) Shopping and office centers between five (5) and twelve (12) acres, inclusive, in size shall be permitted one freestanding sign per street
frontage with a sign face area of one hundred fifty (150) square feet and a maximum overall sign height of twenty feet (20'). These
freestanding signs will take the place of one of the smaller permitted freestanding signs on a one for one basis.
(b) Shopping and office centers greater than twelve (12) acres in size shall be permitted on freestanding sign per street frontage with a sign face
area of two hundred (200) square feet and a maximum overall sign height of twenty feet (20'). These freestanding signs will take the place of
one of the smaller permitted freestanding signs on a one for one basis.
3. Wall Signs: Each tenant in a shopping or office center shall be permitted two (2) square feet of sign area per linear foot of building frontage, if
that tenant's shop or office area is adjacent to a street, alley, parking area or access drive. Sign area shall not be exchanged between walls or
tenants.
(C) Vehicle, Heavy Equipment And Boat Dealership:
1. Freestanding Signs: Each parcel of land which contains one or more vehicle, heavy equipment or boat franchise dealership, shall be permitted
one freestanding sign per franchise. No freestanding sign permitted under this subsection shall be closer than one hundred feet (100') to another
freestanding sign on the same parcel. The sign face area shall not exceed one hundred (100) square feet per franchise and the overall sign
height shall not exceed twenty feet (20'). More than one franchise may be placed on a freestanding sign, provided the total signage on a single
freestanding sign does not exceed three hundred (300) square feet. Dealerships with only one franchise on a legal parcel shall have a maximum
sign face area of one hundred fifty (150) square feet.
2. Wall Signs: Two and one-half (21/2) square feet of sign area per linear foot of building frontage shall be permitted if the building is adjacent to a
public street, parking area or access drive. Sign area shall not be exchanged between walls.
3. Nongovernmental Flags, Pennants, Bunting And Similar Materials: Such advertising media shall be permitted provided they are kept in good
repair. No vinyl, paper or foil decorations shall be displayed for longer than one year or the life of the material whichever is less.
(D) Permanent Outside Retail Sales:
1. With A Building: If a building is on the same property as an outdoor retail sale use (subsection 11-28-6-2(A)), permitted signage shall be the
same as a freestanding retail use.
2. Without A Building: The use shall be allowed one freestanding sign per two hundred fifty feet (250') of street frontage or fraction thereof. The
sign face area shall not exceed sixty (60) square feet, the overall sign height shall not exceed twenty feet (20') and the width shall not exceed
twelve and one-half feet (121/2'). Sign area shall not be exchanged between signs.
(E) Freeway-Oriented Signs:
1. Eligibility: Any parcel within six hundred feet (600') of the Highway 99 right of way which is engaged in one of the following uses may have a
freeway-oriented sign:
(a) A hotel or motel.
(b) A restaurant.
(c) A service station.
(d) A shopping or office center.
(e) A new vehicle, heavy equipment or boat sales lot.
(f) A convenience store.
(g) Any use interpreted by the Planning Commission to be a freeway oriented business. A written request for an interpretation shall be submitted
to the Community Development Department a minimum of five (5) working days before a regularly scheduled meeting to be considered by the
Commission.
2. Design Standards:
(a) No freeway-oriented sign shall be greater than seventy five feet (75') in height to the top of the sign.
(b) The sign face area shall not exceed two hundred (200) square feet.
(c) A single pole shall be used for support.
3. Placement: Freeway-oriented signs shall be setback a minimum of ten feet (10') from Highway 99 to the nearest portion of the sign and shall be
placed in the rear forty percent (40%) of the parcel.
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 401/436
4. Site Plan Review: All freeway-oriented signs shall require a site plan review. Site plan review applications shall be applied for and processed as
per this Title (Chapter 11-20-1).
(F) Miscellaneous Commercial Signs:
1. Service Station Signs: Service stations shall be permitted the same signs as a freestanding retail business (subsection 11-28-6-2(A)) with the
following additions:
(a) Gasoline Price Signs: Service stations shall be permitted one gasoline price sign per street frontage. Price signs shall not exceed twenty (20)
square feet and shall not be mounted higher than twenty feet (20') to the top of the sign. Price signs and the allowed freestanding sign may be
combined.
(b) Gasoline Island Signs: Wall signs not exceeding fifteen (15) square feet shall be allowed on the wall of any gasoline island shelter, provided
that the sign only denotes the station name or brand. Additional miscellaneous signs not exceeding one square foot may be placed on top of
each pump, provided the signs advertise specials, products or services available at the service station. Gasoline island signs shall not require
a sign application.
2. Churches: Churches shall be permitted the following signs:
(a) Freestanding Signs Or Wall Signs: One freestanding sign per street frontage or wall signage not to exceed one and one-half (11/2) square
feet of sign area per linear foot of building frontage, but not both, shall be permitted. Freestanding sign face area shall not exceed forty (40)
square feet and the overall sign height shall not exceed six feet (6'). Sign area shall not be exchanged between signs.
(b) Changeable Copy Signs: One, freestanding or wall, changeable copy sign per street frontage not to exceed twenty (20) square feet. The
changeable copy sign if freestanding shall not exceed a height of six feet (6'). Wall mounted changeable copy signs shall not be mounted
higher than eight feet (8') to the top of the sign. Sign area shall not be exchanged between signs.
3. Temporary And Seasonal Commercial Uses: Temporary and seasonal commercial uses shall be permitted one movable sign not to exceed
sixteen (16) square feet per sign face with a maximum of two (2) sign faces. All movable signs shall be removed when the use is not in
operation, both daily and at the end of the season. Additional signage may be applied under temporary signage (see Section 11-28-7), and all
required fees shall be charged.
4. Bank Signs: Banks and similar financial businesses shall be permitted the same signs as a freestanding retail business (subsection 11-28-6-
2(A)) with the following addition:
(a) Automatic Teller Machine Signs: Banks with automatic teller machines shall be permitted an additional twelve (12) square feet of wall signage
for the exclusive use of advertising the automatic teller machine and posting any operating instructions or notices required for the machine.
Such signage shall be placed on or adjacent to the teller machine.
5. Theaters: Movie and live theaters and similar performance oriented facilities which change their featured performance often shall be permitted
the same signs as a freestanding retail business (subsection 11-28-6-2(A)) with the following additions:
(a) Marquee: Theaters shall be permitted an additional thirty (30) square feet, per stage or theater, for use as a changeable copy marquee. The
marquee shall only be used for advertising current or future features or acts. The Community Development Director shall review the use to
determine if the use qualifies for a marquee.
(b) Playbill Cabinets: Theaters shall be permitted two (2) wall mounted playbill cabinets per stage or theater. Playbill cabinets shall not exceed
twenty (20) square feet each.
6. Fast Food Menu Boards: Fast food restaurants with drive-thru service shall be permitted menu boards, provided that the aggregate square
footage of all menu boards does not exceed seventy five (75) square feet.
7. Changeable Copy Signs: Changeable copy signs shall not exceed forty (40) square feet in area except as permitted by this Chapter. The sign
area shall be counted against the permitted sign area for the type of mounting on which it is placed.
8. Canopy Signs: Advertising on decorative canopies and awnings is permitted. Advertising on canopies and awnings shall count against the
allowable wall signage permitted for the wall on which it is attached.
9. Under-Canopy Signs: Under-canopy signs are permitted for any use which has at least a five foot (5') wide covered walkway. One under canopy
sign per covered entrance is permitted. Under-canopy signs shall not exceed six (6) square feet with a maximum width of three feet (3'), and
shall have a minimum height clearance of eight feet (8').
10. On Site Directional Signs: The community development director shall review on site directional signs for the necessity of the signs and their
locations for function. No directional sign shall be greater than three (3) square feet in sign face area or more than five feet (5') in height. Copy on
such signs shall be limited to such words as: "out", "in" and "one way" and may contain a logo, provided the logo does not exceed one-third (1/3)
of the sign face area.
11. Directory Signs: Directory signs may be placed as needed subject to a review by the community development director.
12. Time And Temperature Signs: A conditional use permit shall be required for all time and temperature signs. Time and temperature signs shall
not exceed eighteen (18) square feet in area. The sign area shall be counted against the permitted sign area for the type of mounting on which it
is placed. Conditional use permits shall be applied for and processed as per chapter 16 of this title.
13. Electronic Reader Board: A conditional use permit shall be required for all electronic reader boards. Electronic reader boards shall not exceed
eight hundred (800) square feet in area and shall not be mounted at a height of more than seventy five feet (75'). The sign area of an electronic
reader board shall not be counted against other permitted signage and may be combined with other permitted signage. Conditional use permits
shall be applied for and processed as per chapter 16 of this title. Electronic reader boards shall not contain any display or illumination which is in
motion or appears to be in motion or changes in intensity or exposes its message for less than four (4) seconds. The interval between messages
shall not be less than one second. (Ord. 95-9, 8-7-1995)
6/3/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=517 402/436
11-28-6-3: INDUSTRIAL SIGNS:
(A) Freestanding Signs: Each industrial complex shall be permitted one freestanding sign per two hundred fifty feet (250') of street frontage or fraction
thereof. The sign face area shall not exceed one hundred (100) square feet and the overall sign height shall not exceed twenty feet (20'). Sign area
shall not be exchanged between signs.
(B) Wall Signs: Each freestanding industrial building shall be permitted one square foot of sign area per linear foot of building frontage adjacent to a
